play.title:
THE TRAGEDIE OF
Anthonie, and Cleopatra.

speech.speaker: Philo.
speech.line: Nay, but this dotage of our Generals
Ore-flowes the meaſure: thoſe his goodly eyes
That o’re the Files and Muſters of the Warre,
Haue glow’d like plated Mars:
Now bend, now turne
The Office and Deuotion of their view
Vpon a Tawny Front. His Captaines heart,
Which in the ſcuffles of great Fights hath burſt
The Buckles on his breſt, reneages all temper,
And is become the Bellowes and the Fan
To coole a Gypſies Luſt.

line.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter Anthony, Cleopatra, her Ladies, the Traine, with Eunuchs fanning her.

speech.line: Looke where they come:
Take but good note, and you ſhall ſee in him
(The triple Pillar of the world) transform’d
Into a Strumpets Foole. Behold and ſee.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: If it be Loue indeed, tell me how much.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: There’s beggery in the loue that can be reckon’d

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Ile ſet a bourne how farre to be belou’d.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Then muſt thou needes finde out new Heauen,
new Earth.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Newes (my good Lord) from Rome.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Grates me, the ſumme.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Nay heare them Anthony.
Fuluia perchance is angry: Or who knowes,
If the ſcarſe-bearded Cæſar haue not ſent
His powrefull Mandate to you. Do this, or this;
Take in that Kingdome, and Infranchiſe that:
Perform’t, or elſe we damne thee.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: How, my Loue?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Perchance? Nay, and moſt like:
You muſt not ſtay heere longer, your diſmiſſion
Is come from Cæſar, therefore heare it Anthony,
Where’s Fuluias Proceſſe? (Cæſars I would ſay) both?
Call in the Meſſengers: As I am Egypts Queene,
Thou bluſheſt Anthony, and that blood of thine
Is Cæſars homager: elſe ſo thy cheeke payes ſhame,
When ſhrill-tongu’d Fuluia ſcolds. The Meſſengers.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Let Rome in Tyber melt, and the wide Arch
Of the raing’d Empire fall: Heere is my ſpace,
Kingdomes are clay: Our dungie earth alike
Feeds Beaſt as Man; the Nobleneſſe of life
Is to do thus: when ſuch a mutuall paire,
And ſuch a twaine can doo’t, in which I binde
One paine of puniſhment, the world to weete
We ſtand vp Peereleſſe.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Excellent falſhood:
Why did he marry Fuluia, and not loue her?
Ile ſeeme the Foole I am not. Anthony will be himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: But ſtirr’d by Cleopatra.
Now for the loue of Loue, and her ſoft houres,
Let’s not confound the time with Conference harſh;
There’s not a minute of our liues ſhould ſtretch
Without ſome pleaſure now. What ſport to night?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Heare the Ambaſſadors.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Fye wrangling Queene:
Whom euery thing becomes, to chide, to laugh,
To weepe: who euery paſſion fully ſtriues
To make it ſelfe (in Thee) faire, and admir’d.
No Meſſenger but thine, and all alone, to night
Wee’l wander through the ſtreets, and note
The qualities of people. Come my Queene,
Laſt night you did deſire it. Speake not to vs.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: Is Cæſar with Anthonius priz’d ſo ſlight?

speech.speaker: Philo.
speech.line: Sir, ſometimes when he is not Anthony,
He comes too ſhort of that great Property
Which ſtill ſhould go with Anthony.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: I am full ſorry, that hee approues the common
Lyar, who thus ſpeakes of him at Rome; but I will hope
of better deeds to morrow. Reſt you happy.

scene.stagedir: Enter Enobarbus, Lamprius, a Southſayer, Rannius, Lucillius, Charmian, Iras, Mardian the Eunuch, and Alexas.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: L. Alexas, ſweet Alexas, moſt any thing Alexas,
almoſt moſt abſolute Alexas, where’s the Soothſayer
that you prais’d ſo to’th’Queene? Oh that I knewe this
Husband, which you ſay, muſt change his Hornes with
Garlands.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Soothſayer.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: Your will?

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Is this the Man? Is’t you ſir that know things?

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: In Natures infinite booke of Secrecie, a little I can read.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Shew him your hand.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Bring in the Banket quickly: Wine enough,
Cleopatra’s health to drinke.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Good ſir, giue me good Fortune.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: I make not, but foreſee.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Pray then, foreſee me one.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: You ſhall be yet farre fairer then you are.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: He meanes in fleſh.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: No, you ſhall paint when you are old.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Wrinkles forbid.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Vex not his preſcience, be attentiue.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Huſh.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: You ſhall be more belouing, then beloued.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: I had rather heate my Liuer with drinking.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Nay, heare him.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Good now ſome excellent Fortune: Let mee
be married to three Kings in a forenoone, and Widdow
them all: Let me haue a Childe at fifty, to whom Herode
of Iewry may do Homage. Finde me to marrie me with
Oƈtauius Cæſar, and companion me with my Miſtris.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: You ſhall out-liue the Lady whom you ſerue.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Oh excellent, I loue long life better then Figs.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: You haue ſeene and proued a fairer former for-
tune, then that which is to approach.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Then belike my Children ſhall haue no names:
Prythee how many Boyes and Wenches muſt I haue.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: If euery of your wiſhes had a wombe, & fore-
tell euery wiſh, a Million.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Out Foole, I forgiue thee for a Witch.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: You thinke none but your ſheets are priuie to
your wiſhes.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Nay come, tell Iras hers.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Wee’l know all our Fortunes.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Mine, and moſt of our Fortunes to night, ſhall
be drunke to bed.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: There’s a Palme preſages Chaſtity, if nothing els.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: E’ne as the o’re-flowing Nylus preſageth Fa-
mine.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: Go you wilde Bedfellow, you cannot Soothſay.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Nay, if an oyly Palme bee not a fruitfull Prog-
noſtication, I cannot ſcratch mine eare. Prythee tel her
but a worky day Fortune.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: Your Fortunes are alike.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: But how, but how, giue me particulars.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: I haue ſaid.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: Am I not an inch of Fortune better then ſhe?

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Well, if you were but an inch of fortune better
then I: where would you chooſe it.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: Not in my Husbands noſe.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Our worſer thoughts Heauens mend.

speech.speaker: Alexas.
speech.line: Come, his Fortune, his Fortune. Oh let him
mary a woman that cannot go, ſweet Iſis, I beſeech thee,
and let her dye too, and giue him a worſe, and let worſe
follow worſe, till the worſt of all follow him laughing to
his graue, fifty-fold a Cuckold. Good Iſis heare me this
Prayer, though thou denie me a matter of more waight:
good Iſis I beſeech thee.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: Amen, deere Goddeſſe, heare that prayer of the
people. For, as it is a heart-breaking to ſee a handſome
man looſe-Wiu’d, ſo it is a deadly ſorrow, to beholde a
foule Knaue vncuckolded: Therefore deere Iſis keep de-
corum, and Fortune him accordingly.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Lo now, if it lay in their hands to make mee a
Cuckold, they would make themſelues Whores, but
they’ld doo’t.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Huſh, heere comes Anthony.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Not he, the Queene.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Saue you, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: No Lady.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Was he not heere?

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: No Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: He was diſpos’d to mirth, but on the ſodaine
A Romane thought hath ſtrooke him.
Enobarbus?

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Seeke him, and bring him hither: wher’s Alexias?

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Heere at your ſeruice.
My Lord approaches.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: We will not looke vpon him:
Go with vs.

speech.speaker: Meſſen.
speech.line: Fuluia thy Wife,
Firſt came into the Field.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Againſt my Brother Lucius?

speech.speaker: Meſſen.
speech.line: I: but ſoone that Warre had end,
And the times ſtate
Made friends of them, ioynting their force ’gainſt Cæſar,
Whoſe better iſſue in the warre from Italy,
Vpon the firſt encounter draue them.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Well, what worſt.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: The Nature of bad newes infeƈts the Teller.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: When it concernes the Foole or Coward: On.
Things that are paſt, are done, with me. ’Tis thus,
Who tels me true, though in his Tale lye death,
I heare him as he flatter’d.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Labienus (this is ſtiffe-newes)
Hath with his Parthian Force
Extended Aſia: from Euphrates his conquering
Banner ſhooke, from Syria to Lydia,
And to Ionia, whil’ſt —

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Anthony thou would’ſt ſay.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Oh my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Speake to me home,
Mince not the generall tongue, name
Cleopatra as ſhe is call’d in Rome:
Raile thou in Fuluia’s phraſe, and taunt my faults
With ſuch full Licenſe, as both Truth and Malice
Haue power to vtter. Oh then we bring forth weeds,
When our quicke windes lye ſtill, and our illes told vs
Is as our earing: fare thee well awhile.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: At your Noble pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: From Scicion how the newes? Speake there.

speech.speaker: 1. Meſ.
speech.line: The man from Scicion,
Is there ſuch an one?

speech.speaker: 2. Meſ.
speech.line: He ſtayes vpon your will.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Let him appeare:
Theſe ſtrong Egyptian Fetters I muſt breake,
Or looſe my ſelfe in dotage.

line.stagedir: Enter another Meſſenger with a Letter.

speech.line: What are you?

speech.speaker: 3. Meſ.
speech.line: Fuluia thy wife is dead.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Where dyed ſhe.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: In Scicion, her length of ſickneſſe,
With what elſe more ſerious,
Importeth thee to know, this beares.

speech.speaker: Antho.
speech.line: Forbeare me
There’s a great Spirit gone, thus did I deſire it:
What our contempts doth often hurle from vs,
We wiſh it ours againe. The preſent pleaſure,
By reuolution lowring, does become
The oppoſite of it ſelfe: ſhe’s good being gon,
The hand could plucke her backe, that ſhou’d her on.
I muſt from this enchanting Queene breake off,
Ten thouſand harmes, more then the illes I know
My idleneſſe doth hatch.
How now Enobarbus.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: What’s your pleaſure, Sir?

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: I muſt with haſte from hence.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Why then we kill all our Women. We ſee how
mortall an vnkindneſſe is to them, if they ſuffer our de-
parture death’s the word.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I muſt be gone.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Vnder a compelling an occaſion, let women die.
It were pitty to caſt them away for nothing, though be-
tweene them and a great cauſe, they ſhould be eſteemed
nothing. Cleopatra catching but the leaſt noyſe of this,
dies inſtantly: I haue ſeene her dye twenty times vppon
farre poorer moment: I do think there is mettle in death,
which commits ſome louing aƈte vpon her, ſhe hath ſuch
a celerity in dying.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: She is cunning paſt mans thought.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Alacke Sir no, her paſſions are made of nothing
but the fineſt part of pure Loue. We cannot cal her winds
and waters, ſighes and teares: They are greater ſtormes
and Tempeſts then Almanackes can report. This cannot
be cunning in her; if it be, ſhe makes a ſhowre of Raine
as well as Ioue.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Would I had neuer ſeene her.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Oh ſir, you had then left vnſeene a wonderfull
peece of worke, which not to haue beene bleſt withall,
would haue diſcredited your Trauaile.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Fuluia is dead.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Sir.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Fuluia is dead.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Fuluia?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Dead.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Why ſir, giue the Gods a thankefull Sacrifice:
when it pleaſeth their Deities to take the wife of a man
from him, it ſhewes to man the Tailors of the earth: com-
forting therein, that when olde Robes are worne out,
there are members to make new. If there were no more
Women but Fuluia, then had you indeede a cut, and the
caſe to be lamented: This greefe is crown’d with Conſo-
lation, your old Smocke brings foorth a new Petticoate,
and indeed the teares liue in an Onion, that ſhould water
this ſorrow.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: The buſineſſe ſhe hath broached in the State,
Cannot endure my abſence.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: And the buſineſſe you haue broach’d heere can-
not be without you, eſpecially that of Cleopatra’s, which
wholly depends on your abode.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: No more light Anſweres:
Let our Officers
Haue notice what we purpoſe. I ſhall breake
The cauſe of our Expedience to the Queene,
And get her loue to part. For not alone
The death of Fuluia, with more vrgent touches
Do ſtrongly ſpeake to vs: but the Letters too
Of many our contriuing Friends in Rome,
Petition vs at home. Sextus Pompeius
Haue giuen the dare to Cæſar, and commands
The Empire of the Sea. Our ſlippery people,
Whoſe Loue is neuer link’d to the deſeruer,
Till his deſerts are paſt, begin to throw
Pompey the great, and all his Dignities
Vpon his Sonne, who high in Name and Power,
Higher then both in Blood and Life, ſtands vp
For the maine Souldier. Whoſe quality going on,
The ſides o’th’world may danger. Much is breeding,
Which like the Courſers heire, hath yet but life,
And not a Serpents poyſon. Say our pleaſure,
To ſuch whoſe places vnder vs, require
Our quicke remoue from hence.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: I ſhall doo’t.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Alexas, and Iras.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Where is he?

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: I did not ſee him ſince.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: See where he is,
Whoſe with him, what he does:
I did not ſend you. If you finde him ſad,
Say I am dauncing: if in Myrth, report
That I am ſodaine ſicke. Quicke, and returne.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Madam, me thinkes if you did loue him deerly,
You do not hold the method, to enforce
The like from him.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: What ſhould I do, I do not?

speech.speaker: Ch.
speech.line: In each thing giue him way, croſſe him in nothing.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Thou teacheſt like a foole: the way to loſe him.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Tempt him not ſo too farre. I wiſh forbeare,
In time we hate that which we often feare.
But heere comes Anthony.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I am ſicke, and ſullen.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: I am ſorry to giue breathing to my purpoſe.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Helpe me away deere Charmian, I ſhall fall,
It cannot be thus long, the ſides of Nature
Will not ſuſtaine it.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Now my deereſt Queene.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Pray you ſtand farther from mee.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I know by that ſame eye ther’s ſome good news.
What ſayes the married woman you may goe?
Would ſhe had neuer giuen you leaue to come.
Let her not ſay ’tis I that keepe you heere,
I haue no power vpon you: Hers you are.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: The Gods beſt know.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Oh neuer was there Queene
So mightily betrayed: yet at the firſt
I ſaw the Treaſons planted.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Cleopatra.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Why ſhould I thinke you can be mine, & true,
(Though you in ſwearing ſhake the Throaned Gods)
Who haue beene falſe to Fuluia?
Riotous madneſſe,
To be entangled with thoſe mouth-made vowes,
Which breake themſelues in ſwearing.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Moſt ſweet Queene.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Nay pray you ſeeke no colour for your going,
But bid farewell, and goe:
When you ſued ſtaying,
Then was the time for words: No going then,
Eternity was in our Lippes, and Eyes,
Bliſſe in our browes bent: none our parts ſo poore,
But was a race of Heauen. They are ſo ſtill,
Or thou the greateſt Souldier of the world,
Art turn’d the greateſt Lyar.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: How now Lady?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I would I had thy inches, thou ſhould’ſt know
There were a heart in Egypt.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Heare me Queene:
The ſtrong neceſſity of Time, commands
Our Seruicles a-while: but my full heart
Remaines in vſe with you. Our Italy,
Shines o’re with ciuill Swords; Sextus Pompeius
Makes his approaches to the Port of Rome,
Equality of two Domeſticke powers,
Breed ſcrupulous faƈtion: The hated growne to ſtrength
Are newly growne to Loue: The condemn’d Pompey,
Rich in his Fathers Honor, creepes apace
Into the hearts of ſuch, as haue not thriued
Vpon the preſent ſtate, whoſe Numbers threaten,
And quietneſſe growne ſicke of reſt, would purge
By any deſperate change: My more particular,
And that which moſt with you ſhould ſafe my going,
Is Fuluias death.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Though age from folly could not giue me freedom
It does from childiſhneſſe. Can Fuluia dye?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: She’s dead my Queene.
Looke heere, and at thy Soueraigne leyſure read
The Garboyles ſhe awak’d: at the laſt, beſt,
See when, and where ſhee died.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: O moſt falſe Loue!
Where be the Sacred Violles thou ſhould’ſt fill
With ſorrowfull water? Now I ſee, I ſee,
In Fuluias death, how mine receiu’d ſhall be.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Quarrell no more, but bee prepar’d to know
The purpoſes I beare: which are, or ceaſe,
As you ſhall giue th’aduice. By the fire
That quickens Nylus ſlime, I go from hence
Thy Souldier, Seruant, making Peace or Warre,
As thou affeƈts.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Cut my Lace, Charmian come,
But let it be, I am quickly ill, and well,
So Anthony loues.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: My precious Queene forbeare,
And giue true euidence to his Loue, which ſtands
An honourable Triall.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: So Fuluia told me.
I prythee turne aſide, and weepe for her,
Then bid adiew to me, and ſay the teares
Belong to Egypt. Good now, play one Scene
Of excellent diſſembling, and let it looke
Like perfeƈt Honor.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: You’l heat my blood no more?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: You can do better yet: but this is meetly.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Now by Sword.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: And Target. Still he mends.
But this is not the beſt. Looke prythee Charmian,
How this Herculean Roman do’s become
The carriage of his chafe.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Ile leaue you Lady.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Courteous Lord, one word:
Sir, you and I muſt part, but that’s not it:
Sir, you and I haue lou’d, but there’s not it:
That you know well, ſomething it is I would:
Oh, my Obliuion is a very Anthony,
And I am all forgotten.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: But that your Royalty
Holds Idleneſſe your ſubieƈt, I ſhould take you
For Idleneſſe it ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: ’Tis ſweating Labour,
To beare ſuch Idleneſſe ſo neere the heart
As Cleopatra this. But Sir, forgiue me,
Since my becommings kill me, when they do not
Eye well to you. Your Honor calles you hence,
Therefore be deafe to my vnpittied Folly,
And all the Gods go with you. Vpon your Sword
Sit Lawrell viƈtory, and ſmooth ſucceſſe
Be ſtrew’d before your feete.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Let vs go.
Come: Our ſeparation ſo abides and flies,
That thou reciding heere, goes yet with mee;
And I hence fleeting, heere remaine with thee.
Away.

scene.stagedir: Enter Oƈtauius reading a Letter, Lepidus, and their Traine.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: You may ſee Lepidus, and henceforth know,
It is not Cæſars Naturall vice, to hate
One great Competitor. From Alexandria
This is the newes: He fiſhes, drinkes, and waſtes
The Lampes of night in reuell: Is not more manlike
Then Cleopatra: nor the Queene of Ptolomy
More Womanly then he. Hardly gaue audience
Or vouchſafe to thinke he had Partners. You
Shall finde there a man, who is th’abſtraƈts of all faults,
That all men follow.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: I muſt not thinke
There are, euils enow to darken all his goodneſſe:
His faults in him, ſeeme as the Spots of Heauen,
More fierie by nights Blackneſſe; Hereditarie,
Rather then purchaſte: what he cannot change,
Then what he chooſes.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: You are too indulgent. Let’s graunt it is not
Amiſſe to tumble on the bed of Ptolomy,
To giue a Kingdome for a Mirth, to ſit
And keepe the turne of Tipling with a Slaue,
To reele the ſtreets at noone, and ſtand the Buffet
With knaues that ſmels of ſweate: Say this becoms him
(As his compoſure muſt be rare indeed,
Whom theſe things cannot blemiſh) yet muſt Anthony
No way excuſe his foyles, when we do beare
So great waight in his lightneſſe. If he fill’d
His vacancie with his Voluptuouſneſſe,
Full ſurfets, and the drineſſe of his bones,
Call on him for’t. But to confound ſuch time,
That drummes him from his ſport, and ſpeakes as lowd
As his owne State, and ours, ’tis to be chid:
As we rate Boyes, who being mature in knowledge,
Pawne their experience to their preſent pleaſure,
And ſo rebell to iudgement.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Heere’s more newes.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Thy biddings haue beene done, & euerie houre
Moſt Noble Cæſar, ſhalt thou haue report
How ’tis abroad. Pompey is ſtrong at Sea,
And it appeares, he is belou’d of thoſe
That only haue feard Cæſar: to the Ports
The diſcontents repaire, and mens reports
Giue him much wrong’d.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: I ſhould haue knowne no leſſe,
It hath bin taught vs from the primall ſtate
That he which is was wiſht, vntill he were:
And the ebb’d man,
Ne’re lou’d, till ne’re worth loue,
Comes fear’d, by being lack’d. This common bodie,
Like to a Vagabond Flagge vpon the Streame,
Goes too, and backe, lacking the varrying tyde
To rot it ſelfe with motion.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Cæſar I bring thee word,
Menacrates and Menas famous Pyrates
Makes the Sea ſerue them, which they eare and wound
With keeles of euery kinde. Many hot inrodes
They make in Italy, the Borders Maritime
Lacke blood to thinke on’t, and fluſh youth reuolt,
No Veſſell can peepe forth: but ’tis as ſoone
Taken as ſeene: for Pompeyes name ſtrikes more
Then could his Warre reſiſted

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Anthony,
Leaue thy laſciuious Vaſſailes. When thou once
Was beaten from Medena, where thou ſlew’ſt
Hirſius, and Pauſa Conſuls, at thy heele
Did Famine follow, whom thou fought’ſt againſt,
(Though daintily brought vp) with patience more
Then Sauages could ſuffer. Thou did’ſt drinke
The ſtale of Horſes, and the gilded Puddle
Which Beaſts would cough at. Thy pallat thē did daine
The rougheſt Berry, on the rudeſt Hedge.
Yea, like the Stagge, when Snow the Paſture ſheets,
The barkes of Trees thou brows’d. On the Alpes,
It is reported thou did’ſt eate ſtrange fleſh,
Which ſome did dye to looke on: And all this
(It wounds thine Honor that I ſpeake it now)
Was borne ſo like a Soldiour, that thy cheeke
So much as lank’d not.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: ’Tis pitty of him.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Let his ſhames quickely
Driue him to Rome, ’tis time we twaine
Did ſhew our ſelues i’th’Field, and to that end
Aſſemble me immediate counſell, Pompey
Thriues in our Idleneſſe.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: To morrow Cæſar,
I ſhall be furniſht to informe you rightly
Both what by Sea and Land I can be able
To front this preſent time.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Til which encounter, it is my buſines too. Farwell.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Farwell my Lord, what you ſhal know mean time
Of ſtirres abroad, I ſhall beſeech you Sir
To let me be partaker.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Doubt not ſir, I knew it for my Bond.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Charmian.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Ha, ha, giue me to drinke Mandragora.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Why Madam?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: That I might ſleepe out this great gap of time:
My Anthony is away.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: You thinke of him too much.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: O ’tis Treaſon.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Madam, I truſt not ſo.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Thou, Eunuch Mardian?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: What’s your Highneſſe pleaſure?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Not now to heare thee ſing. I take no pleaſure
In ought an Eunuch ha’s: Tis well for thee,
That being vnſeminar’d, thy freer thoughts
May not flye forth of Egypt. Haſt thou Affeƈtions?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Yes gracious Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Indeed?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Not in deed Madam, for I can do nothing
But what in deede is honeſt to be done:
Yet haue I fierce Affeƈtions, and thinke
What Venus did with Mars.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Oh Charmion:
Where think’ſt thou he is now? Stands he, or ſits he?
Or does he walke? Or is he on his Horſe?
Oh happy horſe to beare the weight of Anthony!
Do brauely Horſe, for wot’ſt thou whom thou moou’ſt,
The demy Atlas of this Earth, the Arme
And Burganet of men. Hee’s ſpeaking now,
Or murmuring, where’s my Serpent of old Nyle,
(For ſo he cals me:) Now I feede my ſelfe
With moſt delicious poyſon. Thinke on me
That am with Phœbus amorous pinches blacke,
And wrinkled deepe in time. Broad-fronted Cæſar,
When thou was’t heere aboue the ground, I was
A morſell for a Monarke: and great Pompey
Would ſtand and make his eyes grow in my brow,
There would he anchor his Aſpeƈt, and dye
With looking on his life.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Soueraigne of Egypt, haile.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: How much vnlike art thou Marke Anthony?
Yet comming from him, that great Med’cine hath
With his Tinƈt gilded thee.
How goes it with my braue Marke Anthonie?

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Laſt thing he did (deere Queene)
He kiſt the laſt of many doubled kiſſes
This Orient Pearle. His ſpeech ſtickes in my heart.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Mine eare muſt plucke it thence.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Good Friend, quoth he:
Say the firme Roman to great Egypt ſends
This treaſure of an Oyſter: at whoſe foote
To mend the petty preſent, I will peece
Her opulent Throne, with Kingdomes. All the Eaſt,
(Say thou) ſhall call her Miſtris. So he nodded,
And ſoberly did mount an Arme-gaunt Steede,
Who neigh’d ſo hye, that what I would haue ſpoke,
Was beaſtly dumbe by him.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: What was he ſad, or merry?

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Like to the time o’th’yeare, between ý extremes
Of hot and cold, he was nor ſad nor merrie.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Oh well diuided diſpoſition: Note him,
Note him good Charmian, ’tis the man; but note him.
He was not ſad, for he would ſhine on thoſe
That make their lookes by his. He was not merrie,
Which ſeem’d to tell them, his remembrance lay
In Egypt with his ioy, but betweene both.
Oh heauenly mingle! Bee’ſt thou ſad, or merrie,
The violence of either thee becomes,
So do’s it no mans elſe. Met’ſt thou my Poſts?

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: I Madam, twenty ſeuerall Meſſengers.
Why do you ſend ſo thicke?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Who’s borne that day, when I forget to ſend
to Anthonie, ſhall dye a Begger. Inke and paper Char-
mian. Welcome my good Alexas. Did I Charmian, e-
uer loue Cæſar ſo?

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Oh that braue Cæſar!

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Be choak’d with ſuch another Emphaſis,
Say the braue Anthony.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: The valiant Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: By Iſis, I will giue thee bloody teeth,
If thou with Cæſar Paragon againe:
My man of men.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: By your moſt gracious pardon,
I ſing but after you.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: My Sallad dayes,
When I was greene in iudgement, cold in blood,
To ſay, as I ſaide then. But come, away,
Get me Inke and Paper,
he ſhall haue euery day a ſeuerall greeting, or Ile vnpeo-
ple Egypt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Pompey, Menecrates, and Menas, in warlike manner.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: If the great Gods be iuſt, they ſhall aſſiſt
The deeds of iuſteſt men.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Know worthy Pompey, that what they do de-
lay, they not deny.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Whiles we are ſutors to their Throne, decayes
the thing we ſue for.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: We ignorant of our ſelues,
Begge often our owne harmes, which the wiſe Powres
Deny vs for our good: ſo finde we profit
By looſing of our Prayers.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: I ſhall do well:
The people loue me, and the Sea is mine;
My powers are Creſſent, and my Auguring hope
Sayes it will come to’th’full. Marke Anthony
In Egypt ſits at dinner, and will make
No warres without doores. Cæſar gets money where
He looſes hearts: Lepidus flatters both,
Of both is flatter’d: but he neither loues,
Nor either cares for him.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Cæſar and Lepidus are in the field,
A mighty ſtrength they carry.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Where haue you this? ’Tis falſe.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: From Siluius, Sir.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: He dreames: I know they are in Rome together
Looking for Anthony: but all the charmes of Loue,
Salt Cleopatra ſoften thy wand lip,
Let Witchcraft ioyne with Beauty, Luſt with both,
Tye vp the Libertine in a field of Feaſts,
Keepe his Braine fuming. Epicurean Cookes,
Sharpen with cloyleſſe ſawce his Appetite,
That ſleepe and feeding may prorogue his Honour,
Euen till a Lethied dulneſſe —
How now Varrius?

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: This is moſt certaine, that I ſhall deliuer:
Marke Anthony is euery houre in Rome
Expeƈted. Since he went from Egypt, ’tis
A ſpace for farther Trauaile.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: I could haue giuen leſſe matter
A better eare. Menas, I did not thinke
This amorous Surfetter would haue donn’d his Helme
For ſuch a petty Warre: His Souldierſhip
Is twice the other twaine: But let vs reare
The higher our Opinion, that our ſtirring
Can from the lap of Egypts Widdow, plucke
The neere Luſt-wearied Anthony.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: I cannot hope,
Cæſar and Anthony ſhall well greet together;
His Wife that’s dead, did treſpaſſes to Cæſar,
His Brother wan’d vpon him, although I thinke
Not mou’d by Anthony.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: I know not Menas,
How leſſer Enmities may giue way to greater,
Were’t not that we ſtand vp againſt them all:
’Twer pregnant they ſhould ſquare between themſelues,
For they haue entertained cauſe enough
To draw their ſwords: but how the feare of vs
May Ciment their diuiſions, and binde vp
The petty difference, we yet not know:
Bee’t as our Gods will haue’t; it onely ſtands
Our liues vpon, to vſe our ſtrongeſt hands
Come Menas.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Good Enobarbus, ’tis a worthy deed,
And ſhall become you well, to intreat your Captaine
To ſoft and gentle ſpeech.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: I ſhall intreat him
To anſwer like himſelfe: if Cæſar moue him,
Let Anthony looke ouer Cæſars head,
And ſpeake as lowd as Mars. By Iupiter,
Were I the wearer of Anthonio’s Beard,
I would not ſhaue’t to day.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: ’Tis not a time for priuate ſtomacking.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Euery time ſerues for the matter that is then
borne in’t.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: But ſmall to greater matters muſt giue way.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Not if the ſmall come firſt.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Your ſpeech is paſſion: but pray you ſtirre
No Embers vp. Heere comes the Noble Anthony.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: And yonder Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: If we compoſe well heere, to Parthia:
Hearke Ventidius.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: I do not know Mecenas, aske Agrippa.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Noble Friends:
That which combin’d vs was moſt great, and let not
A leaner aƈtion rend vs. What’s amiſſe,
May it be gently heard. When we debate
Our triuiall difference loud, we do commit
Murther in healing wounds. Then Noble Partners,
The rather for I earneſtly beſeech,
Touch you the ſowreſt points with ſweeteſt tearmes,
Nor curſtneſſe grow to’th’matter.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: ’Tis ſpoken well:
Were we before our Armies, and to fight,
I ſhould do thus.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Welcome to Rome.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Thanke you.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Sit.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Sit ſir.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Nay then.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I learne, you take things ill, which are not ſo:
Or being, concerne you not.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: I muſt be laught at, if or for nothing, or a little, I
Should ſay my ſelfe offended, and with you
Chiefely i’th’world. More laught at, that I ſhould
Once name you derogately: when to ſound your name
It not concern’d me.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: My being in Egypt Cæſar, what was’t to you?

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: No more then my reciding heere at Rome
Might be to you in Egypt: yet if you there
Did praƈtiſe on my State, your being in Egypt
Might be my queſtion.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: How intend you, praƈtis’d?

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: You may be pleas’d to catch at mine intent,
By what did heere befall me. Your Wife and Brother
Made warres vpon me, and their conteſtation
Was Theame for you, you were the word of warre.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: You do miſtake your buſines, my Brother neuer
Did vrge me in his Aƈt: I did inquire it.
And haue my Learning from ſome true reports
That drew their ſwords with you, did he not rather
Diſcredit my authority with yours,
And make the warres alike againſt my ſtomacke,
Hauing alike your cauſe. Of this, my Letters
Before did ſatisfie you. If you’l patch a quarrell,
As matter whole you haue to make it with,
It muſt not be with this.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: You praiſe your ſelfe, by laying defeƈts of iudge-
ment to me: but you patcht vp your excuſes.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Not ſo, not ſo:
I know you could not lacke, I am certaine on’t,
Very neceſſity of this thought, that I
Your Partner in the cauſe ’gainſt which he fought,
Could not with gracefull eyes attend thoſe Warres
Which fronted mine owne peace. As for my wife,
I would you had her ſpirit, in ſuch another,
The third oth’world is yours, which with a Snaffle,
You may pace eaſie, but not ſuch a wife.

speech.speaker: Enobar.
speech.line: Would we had all ſuch wiues, that the men
might go to Warres with the women.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: So much vncurbable, her Garboiles (Cæſar)
Made out of her impatience: which not wanted
Shrodeneſſe of policie to: I greeuing grant,
Did you too much diſquiet, for that you muſt,
But ſay I could not helpe it.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: I wrote to you, when rioting in Alexandria you
Did pocket vp my Letters: and with taunts
Did gibe my Miſiue out of audience.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Sir, he fell vpon me, ere admitted, then:
Three Kings I had newly feaſted, and did want
Of what I was i’th’morning: but next day
I told him of my ſelfe, which was as much
As to haue askt him pardon. Let this Fellow
Be nothing of our ſtrife: if we contend
Out of our queſtion wipe him.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: You haue broken the Article of your oath,
which you ſhall neuer haue tongue to charge me with.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Soft Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: No Lepidus, let him ſpeake,
The Honour is Sacred which he talks on now,
Suppoſing that I lackt it: but on Cæſar,
The Article of my oath.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: To lend me Armes, and aide when I requir’d
them, the which you both denied.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Negleƈted rather:
And then when poyſoned houres had bound me vp
From mine owne knowledge, as neerely as I may,
Ile play the penitent to you. But mine honeſty,
Shall not make poore my greatneſſe, nor my power
Worke without it. Truth is, that Fuluia,
To haue me out of Egypt, made Warres heere,
For which my ſelfe, the ignorant motiue, do
So farre aske pardon, as befits mine Honour
To ſtoope in ſuch a caſe.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: ’Tis Noble ſpoken.

speech.speaker: Mece.
speech.line: If it might pleaſe you, to enforce no further
The griefes betweene ye: to forget them quite,
Were to remember: that the preſent neede,
Speakes to attone you.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Worthily ſpoken Mecenas.

speech.speaker: Enobar.
speech.line: Or if you borrow one anothers Loue for the
inſtant, you may when you heare no more words of
Pompey returne it againe: you ſhall haue time to wrangle
in, when you haue nothing elſe to do.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Thou art a Souldier, onely ſpeake no more.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: That trueth ſhould be ſilent, I had almoſt for-
got.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: You wrong this preſence, therefore ſpeake no
more.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Go too then: your Conſiderate ſtone.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: I do not much diſlike the matter, but
The manner of his ſpeech: for’t cannot be,
We ſhall remaine in friendſhip, our conditions
So diffring in their aƈts. Yet if I knew,
What Hoope ſhould hold vs ſtaunch from edge to edge
Ath’world: I would perſue it.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: Giue me leaue Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Speake Agrippa.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: Thou haſt a Siſter by the Mothers ſide, admir’d
Oƈtauia: Great Mark Anthony is now a widdower.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Say not, ſay Agrippa; if Cleopater heard you, your
proofe were well deſerued of raſhneſſe.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: I am not marryed Cæſar: let me heere Agrippa
further ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: To hold you in perpetuall amitie,
To make you Brothers, and to knit your hearts
With an vn-ſlipping knot, take Anthony,
Oƈtauia to his wife: whoſe beauty claimes
No worſe a husband then the beſt of men: whoſe
Vertue, and whoſe generall graces, ſpeake
That which none elſe can vtter. By this marriage,
All little Ielouſies which now ſeeme great,
And all great feares, which now import their dangers,
Would then be nothing. Truth’s would be tales,
Where now halfe tales be truth’s: her loue to both,
Would each to other, and all loues to both
Draw after her. Pardon what I haue ſpoke,
For ’tis a ſtudied not a preſent thought,
By duty ruminated.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Will Cæſar ſpeake?

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Not till he heares how Anthony is toucht,
With what is ſpoke already.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: What power is in Agrippa,
If I would ſay Agrippa, be it ſo,
To make this good?

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: The power of Cæſar,
And his power, vnto Oƈtauia.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: May I neuer
(To this good purpoſe, that ſo fairely ſhewes)
Dreame of impediment: let me haue thy hand
Further this aƈt of Grace: and from this houre,
The heart of Brothers gouerne in our Loues,
And ſway our great Deſignes.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: There’s my hand:
A Siſter I bequeath you, whom no Brother
Did euer loue ſo deerely. Let her liue
To ioyne our kingdomes, and our hearts, and neuer
Flie off our Loues againe.

speech.speaker: Lepi.
speech.line: Happily, Amen.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I did not think to draw my Sword ’gainſt Pompey,
For he hath laid ſtrange courteſies, and great
Of late vpon me. I muſt thanke him onely,
Leaſt my remembrance, ſuffer ill report:
At heele of that, defie him.

speech.speaker: Lepi.
speech.line: Time cals vpon’s,
Of vs muſt Pompey preſently be ſought,
Or elſe he ſeekes out vs.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Where lies he?

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: About the Mount-Meſena.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: What is his ſtrength by land?

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Great, and encreaſing:
But by Sea he is an abſolute Maſter.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: So is the Fame.
Would we had ſpoke together. Haſt we for it,
Yet ere we put our ſelues in Armes, diſpatch we
The buſineſſe we haue talkt of.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: With moſt gladneſſe,
And do inuite you to my Siſters view,
Whether ſtraight Ile lead you.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Let vs Lepidus not lacke your companie.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Noble Anthony, not ſickeneſſe ſhould detaine
me.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Exit omnes. Manet Enobarbus, Agrippa, Mecenas.

speech.speaker: Mec.
speech.line: Welcome from Ægypt Sir.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Halfe the heart of Cæſar, worthy Mecenas. My
honourable Friend Agrippa.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: Good Enobarbus.

speech.speaker: Mece.
speech.line: We haue cauſe to be glad, that matters are ſo
well diſgeſted: you ſtaid well by’t in Egypt.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: I Sir, we did ſleepe day out of countenaunce:
and made the night light with drinking.

speech.speaker: Mece.
speech.line: Eight Wilde-Boares roſted whole at a break-
faſt: and but twelue perſons there. Is this true?

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: This was but as a Flye by an Eagle: we had much
more monſtrous matter of Feaſt, which worthily deſer-
ued noting.

speech.speaker: Mecenas.
speech.line: She’s a moſt triumphant Lady, if report be
ſquare to her.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: When ſhe firſt met Marke Anthony, ſhe purſt
vp his heart vpon the Riuer of Sidnis.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: There ſhe appear’d indeed: or my reporter de-
uis’d well for her.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: I will tell you,
The Barge ſhe ſat in, like a burniſht Throne
Burnt on the water: the Poope was beaten Gold,
Purple the Sailes: and ſo perfumed that
The Windes were Loue-ſicke.
With them the Owers were Siluer,
Which to the tune of Flutes kept ſtroke, and made
The water which they beate, to follow faſter;
As amorous of their ſtrokes. For her owne perſon,
It beggerd all diſcription, ſhe did lye
In her Pauillion, cloth of Gold, of Tiſſue,
O’re-piƈturing that Venns, where we ſee
The fancie out-worke Nature. On each ſide her,
Stood pretty Dimpled Boyes, like ſmiling Cupids,
With diuers coulour’d Fannes whoſe winde did ſeeme,
To gloue the delicate cheekes which they did coole,
And what they vndid did.

speech.speaker: Agrip.
speech.line: Oh rare for Anthony.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Her Gentlewoman, like the Nereides,
So many Mer-maides tended her i’th’eyes,
And made their bends adornings. At the Helme,
A ſeeming Mer-maide ſteeres: The Silken Tackle,
Swell with the touches of thoſe Flower-ſoft hands,
That yarely frame the office. From the Barge
A ſtrange inuiſible perfume hits the ſenſe
Of the adiacent Wharfes. The Citty caſt
Her people out vpon her: and Anthony
Enthron’d i’th’Market-place, did ſit alone,
Whiſling to’th’ayre: which but for vacancie,
Had gone to gaze on Cleopater too,
And made a gap in Nature.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: Rare Egiptian.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Vpon her landing, Anthony ſent to her,
Inuited her to Supper: ſhe replyed,
It ſhould be better, he became her gueſt:
Which ſhe entreated, our Courteous Anthony,
Whom nere the word of no woman hard ſpeake,
Being barber’d ten times o’re, goes to the Feaſt;
And for his ordinary, paies his heart,
For what his eyes eate onely.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: Royall Wench:
She made great Cæſar lay his Sword to bed,
He ploughed her, and ſhe cropt.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: I ſaw her once
Hop forty Paces through the publicke ſtreete,
And hauing loſt her breath, ſhe ſpoke, and panted,
That ſhe did make defeƈt, perfeƈtion,
And breathleſſe powre breath forth.

speech.speaker: Mece.
speech.line: Now Anthony, muſt leaue her vtterly.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Neuer he will not:
Age cannot wither her, nor cuſtome ſtale
Her infinite variety: other women cloy
The appetites they feede, but ſhe makes hungry,
Where moſt ſhe ſatisfies. For vildeſt things
Become themſelues in her, that the holy Prieſts
Bleſſe her, when ſhe is Riggiſh.

speech.speaker: Mece.
speech.line: If Beauty, Wiſedome, Modeſty, can ſettle
The heart of Anthony: Oƈtauia is
A bleſſed Lottery to him.

speech.speaker: Agrip.
speech.line: Let vs go. Good Enobarbus, make your ſelfe
my gueſt, whilſt you abide heere.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Humbly Sir I thanke you.

scene.stagedir: Enter Anthony, Cæſar, Oƈtauia betweene them.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: The world, and my great office, will
Sometimes deuide me from your boſome.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: All which time, before the Gods my knee ſhall
bowe my prayers to them for you.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Goodnight Sir. My Oƈtauia
Read not my blemiſhes in the worlds report:
I haue not kept my ſquare, but that to come
Shall all be done byth’Rule: good night deere Lady:
Good night Sir.

speech.speaker: Cæſar
speech.line: Goodnight.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Now ſirrah: you do wiſh your ſelfe in Egypt?

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: Would I had neuer come from thence, nor you
thither.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: If you can, your reaſon?

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: I ſee it in my motion: haue it not in my tongue,
But yet hie you to Egypt againe.

speech.speaker: Antho.
speech.line: Say to me, whoſe Fortunes ſhall riſe higher
Cæſars or mine?

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: Cæſars. Therefore (oh Anthony) ſtay not by his ſide
Thy Dæmon that thy ſpirit which keepes thee, is
Noble, Couragious, high vnmatchable,
Where Cæſars is not. But neere him, thy Angell
Becomes a feare: as being o’re-powr’d, therefore
Make ſpace enough betweene you.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Speake this no more.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: To none but thee no more but: when to thee,
If thou doſt play with him at any game,
Thou art ſure to looſe: And of that Naturall lucke,
He beats thee ’gainſt the oddes. Thy Luſter thickens,
When he ſhines by: I ſay againe, thy ſpirit
Is all affraid to gouerne thee neere him:
But he alway ’tis Noble.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Get thee gone:
Say to Ventigius I would ſpeake with him. Exit.
He ſhall to Parthia, be it Art or hap,
He hath ſpoken true. The very Dice obey him,
And in our ſports my better cunning faints,
Vnder his chance, if we draw lots he ſpeeds,
His Cocks do winne the Battaile, ſtill of mine,
When it is all to naught: and his Quailes euer
Beate mine (in hoopt) at odd’s. I will to Egypte:
And though I make this marriage for my peace,
I’th’Eaſt my pleaſure lies. Oh come Ventigius.
You muſt to Parthia, your Commiſſions ready:
Follow me, and reciue’t.

speech.speaker: Lepidus.
speech.line: Trouble your ſelues no further: pray you
haſten your Generals after.

speech.speaker: Agr.
speech.line: Sir, Marke Anthony, will e’ne but kiſſe Oƈtauia,
and weele follow.

speech.speaker: Lepi.
speech.line: Till I ſhall ſee you in your Souldiers dreſſe,
Which will become you both: Farewell.

speech.speaker: Mece.
speech.line: We ſhall: as I conceiue the iourney, be at
Mount before you Lepidus.

speech.speaker: Lepi.
speech.line: Your way is ſhorter, my purpoſes do draw me
much about, you’le win two dayes vpon me.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Sir good ſucceſſe.

speech.speaker: Lepi
speech.line: Farewell.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cleopater, Charmian, Iras, and Alexas.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Giue me ſome Muſicke: Muſicke, moody foode
of vs that trade in Loue.

speech.speaker: Omnes.
speech.line: The Muſicke, hoa.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Let it alone, let’s to Billiards: come Charmian.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: My arme is ſore, beſt play with Mardian.

speech.speaker: Cleopa.
speech.line: As well a woman with an Eunuch plaide, as
with a woman. Come you’le play with me Sir?

speech.speaker: Mardi.
speech.line: As well as I can Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: And when good will is ſhewed,
Though’t come to ſhort
The Aƈtor may pleade pardon. Ile none now,
Giue me mine Angle, weele to’th’Riuer there
My Muſicke playing farre off. I will betray
Tawny fine fiſhes, my bended hooke ſhall pierce
Their ſlimy iawes: and as I draw them vp,
Ile thinke them euery one an Anthony,
And ſay, ah ha; y’are caught.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: ’Twas merry when you wager’d on your Ang-
ling, when your diuer did hang a ſalt fiſh on his hooke
which he with feruencie drew vp.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: That time? Oh times:
I laught him out of patience: and that night
I laught him into patience, and next morne,
Ere the ninth houre, I drunke him to his bed:
Then put my Tires and Mantles on him, whilſt
I wore his Sword Phillippan. Oh from Italie,
Ramme thou thy fruitefull tidings in mine eares,
That long time haue bin barren.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Madam, Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Anthonyo’s dead.
If thou ſay ſo Villaine, thou kil’ſt thy Miſtris:
But well and free, if thou ſo yeild him.
There is Gold, and heere
My bleweſt vaines to kiſſe: a hand that Kings
Haue lipt, and trembled kiſſing.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Firſt Madam, he is well.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Why there’s more Gold.
But ſirrah marke, we vſe
To ſay, the dead are well: bring it to that,
The Gold I giue thee, will I melt and powr
Downe thy ill vttering throate.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Good Madam heare me.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Well, go too I will:
But there’s no goodneſſe in thy face if Anthony
Be free and healthfull; ſo tart a fauour
To trumpet ſuch good tidings. If not well,
Thou ſhouldſt come like a Furie crown’d with Snakes,
Not like a formall man.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Wilt pleaſe you heare me?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I haue a mind to ſtrike thee ere thou ſpeak’ſt:
Yet if thou ſay Anthony liues, ’tis well,
Or friends with Cæſar, or not Captiue to him,
Ile ſet thee in a ſhower of Gold, and haile
Rich Pearles vpon thee.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Madam, he’s well.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Well ſaid.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: And Friends with Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Th’art an honeſt man.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Cæſar, and he, are greater Friends then euer.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Make thee a Fortune from me.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: But yet Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I do not like but yet, it does alay
The good precedence, fie vpon but yet,
But yet is as a Iaylor to bring foorth
Some monſtrous Malefaƈtor. Prythee Friend,
Powre out the packe of matter to mine eare,
The good and bad together: he’s friends with Cæſar,
In ſtate of health thou ſaiſt, and thou ſaiſt, free.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Free Madam, no: I made no ſuch report,
He’s bound vnto Oƈtauia.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: For what good turne?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: For the beſt turne i’th’bed.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I am pale Charmian.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Madam, he’s married to Oƈtauia.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: The moſt infeƈtious Peſtilence vpon thee.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Good Madam patience.

speech.speaker: Cleo
speech.line: What ſay you? Strikes him.
Hence horrible Villaine, or Ile ſpurne thine eyes
Like balls before me: Ile vnhaire thy head,

line.stagedir: She hales him vp and downe.

speech.line: Thou ſhalt be whipt with Wyer, and ſtew’d in brine,
Smarting in lingring pickle.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Gratious Madam,
I that do bring the newes, made not the match.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Say ’tis not ſo, a Prouince I will giue thee,
And make thy Fortunes proud: the blow thou had’ſt
Shall make thy peace, for mouing me to rage,
And I will boot thee with what guift beſide
Thy modeſtie can begge.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: He’s married Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo
speech.line: Rogue, thou haſt liu’d too long.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Nay then Ile runne:
What meane you Madam, I haue made no fault.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Good Madam keepe your ſelfe within your ſelfe,
The man is innocent.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Some Innocents ſcape not the thunderbolt:
Melt Egypt into Nyle: and kindly creatures
Turne all to Serpents. Call the ſlaue againe,
Though I am mad, I will not byte him: Call?

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: He is afeard to come.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I will not hurt him,
Theſe hands do lacke Nobility, that they ſtrike
A meaner then my ſelfe: ſince I my ſelfe
Haue giuen my ſelfe the cauſe. Come hither Sir.
Though it be honeſt, it is neuer good
To bring bad newes: giue to a gratious Meſſage
An hoſt of tongues, but let ill tydings tell
Themſelues, when they be felt.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: I haue done my duty.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Is he married?
I cannot hate thee worſer then I do,
If thou againe ſay yes.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: He’s married Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: The Gods confound thee,
Doſt thou hold there ſtill?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Should I lye Madame?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Oh, I would thou didſt:
So halfe my Egypt were ſubmerg’d and made
A Ceſterne for ſcal’d Snakes. Go get thee hence,
Had’ſt thou Narciſſus in thy face to me,
Thou would’ſt appeere moſt vgly: He is married?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: I craue your Highneſſe pardon.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: He is married?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Take no offence, that I would not offend you,
To punniſh me for what you make me do
Seemes much vnequall, he’s married to Oƈtauia.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Oh that his fault ſhould make a knaue of thee,
That art not what th’art ſure of. Get thee hence,
The Marchandize which thou haſt brought from Rome
Are all too deere for me:
Lye they vpon thy hand, and be vndone by em.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Good your Highneſſe patience.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: In prayſing Anthony, I haue diſprais’d Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Many times Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I am paid for’t now: lead me from hence,
I faint, oh Iras, Charmian: ’tis no matter.
Go to the Fellow, good Alexas bid him
Report the feature of Oƈtauia: her yeares,
Her inclination, let him not leaue out
The colour of her haire. Bring me word quickly,
Let him for euer go, let him not Charmian,
Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon,
The other wayes a Mars. Bid you Alexas
Bring me word, how tall ſhe is: pitty me Charmian,
But do not ſpeake to me. Lead me to my Chamber.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter Pompey, at one doore with Drum and Trumpet: at another Cæſar, Lepidus, Anthony, Enobarbus, Mecenas, Agrippa, Menas with Souldiers Marching.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Your Hoſtages I haue, ſo haue you mine:
And we ſhall talke before we fight.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Moſt meete that firſt we come to words,
And therefore haue we
Our written purpoſes before vs ſent,
Which if thou haſt conſidered, let vs know,
If ’twill tye vp thy diſcontented Sword,
And carry backe to Cicelie much tall youth,
That elſe muſt periſh heere.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: To you all three,
The Senators alone of this great world,
Chiefe Faƈtors for the Gods. I do not know,
Wherefore my Father ſhould reuengers want,
Hauing a Sonne and Friends, ſince Iulius Cæſar,
Who at Phillippi the good Brutus ghoſted,
There ſaw you labouring for him. What was’t
That mou’d pale Caſſius to conſpire? And what
Made all-honor’d, honeſt, Romaine Brutus,
With the arm’d reſt, Courtiers of beautious freedome,
To drench the Capitoll, but that they would
Haue one man but a man, and that his it
Hath made me rigge my Nauie. At whoſe burthen,
The anger’d Ocean fomes, with which I meant
To ſcourge th’ingratitude, that deſpightfull Rome
Caſt on my Noble Father.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Take your time.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Thou can’ſt not feare vs Pompey with thy ſailes.
Weele ſpeake with thee at Sea. At land thou know’ſt
How much we do o’re-count thee.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: At Land indeed
Thou doſt orecount me of my Fatherrs houſe:
But ſince the Cuckoo buildes not for himſelfe,
Remaine in’t as thou maiſt.

speech.speaker: Lepi.
speech.line: Be pleas’d to tell vs,
(For this is from the preſent how you take)
The offers we haue ſent you.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: There’s the point.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Which do not be entreated too,
But waigh what it is worth imbrac’d

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: And what may follow to try a larger Fortune.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: You haue made me offer
Of Cicelie, Sardinia: and I muſt
Rid all the Sea of Pirats. Then, to ſend
Meaſures of Wheate to Rome: this greed vpon,
To part with vnhackt edges, and beare backe
Our Targes vndinted.

speech.speaker: Omnes.
speech.line: That’s our offer.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Know then I came before you heere,
A man prepar’d
To take this offer. But Marke Anthony,
Put me to ſome impatience: though I looſe
The praiſe of it by telling. You muſt know
When Cæſar and your Brother were at blowes,
Your Mother came to Cicelie, and did finde
Her welcome Friendly.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I haue heard it Pompey,
And am well ſtudied for a liberall thanks,
Which I do owe you.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Let me haue your hand:
I did not thinke Sir, to haue met you heere,

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: The beds i’th’Eaſt are ſoft, and thanks to you,
That cal’d me timelier then my purpoſe hither:
For I haue gained by’t.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Since I ſaw you laſt, ther’s a change vpon you.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Well, I know not,
What counts harſh Fortune caſt’s vpon my face,
But in my boſome ſhall ſhe neuer come,
To make my heart her vaſſaile.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Well met heere.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: I hope ſo Lepidus, thus we are agreed:
I craue our compoſion may be written
And ſeal’d betweene vs,

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: That’s the next to do.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Weele feaſt each other, ere we part, and lett’s
Draw lots who ſhall begin.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: That will I Pompey.

speech.speaker: Pompey.
speech.line: No Anthony take the lot: but firſt or laſt,
your fine Egyptian cookerie ſhall haue the fame, I haue
heard that Iulius Cæſar, grew fat with feaſting there.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: You haue heard much.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: I haue faire meaning Sir.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: And faire words to them.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Then ſo much haue I heard,
And I haue heard Appolodorus carried —

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: No more that: he did ſo.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: What I pray you?

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: A certaine Queene to Cæſar in a Matris.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: I know thee now, how far’ſt thou Souldier?

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Well, and well am like to do, for I perceiue
Foure Feaſts are toward.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Let me ſhake thy hand,
I neuer hated thee: I haue ſeene thee fight,
When I haue enuied thy behauiour.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Sir, I neuer lou’d you much, but I ha’ prais’d ye,
When you haue well deſeru’d ten times as much,
As I haue ſaid you did.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Inioy thy plainneſſe,
It nothing ill becomes thee:
Aboord my Gally, I inuite you all.
Will you leade Lords?

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Shew’s the way, ſir.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Come. Exeunt. Manet Enob. & Menas

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Thy Father Pompey would ne’re haue made this
Treaty. You, and I haue knowne ſir.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: At Sea, I thinke.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: We haue Sir.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: You haue done well by water.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: And you by Land.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: I will praiſe any man that will praiſe me, thogh
it cannot be denied what I haue done by Land.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Nor what I haue done by water.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Yes ſome-thing you can deny for your owne
ſafety: you haue bin a great Theefe by Sea.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: And you by Land.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: There I deny my Land ſeruice: but giue mee
your hand Menas, if our eyes had authority, heere they
might take two Theeues kiſſing.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: All mens faces are true, whatsomere their hands
are.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: But there is neuer a fayre Woman, ha’s a true
Face.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: No ſlander, they ſteale hearts.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: We came hither to fight with you.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: For my part, I am ſorry it is turn’d to a Drink-
ing. Pompey doth this day laugh away his Fortune.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: If he do, ſure he cannot weep’t backe againe.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Y’haue ſaid Sir, we look’d not for Marke An-
thony heere, pray you, is he married to Cleopatra?

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Cæſars Siſter is call’d Oƈtauia.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: True Sir, ſhe was the wife of Caius Marcellus.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: But ſhe is now the wife of Marcus Anthonius.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Pray’ye ſir.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: ’Tis true.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Then is Cæſar and he, for euer knit together.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: If I were bound to Diuine of this vnity, I wold
not Propheſie ſo.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: I thinke the policy of that purpoſe, made more
in the Marriage, then the loue of the parties.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: I thinke ſo too. But you ſhall finde the band
that ſeemes to tye their friendſhip together, will bee the
very ſtrangler of their Amity: Oƈtauia is of a holy, cold,
and ſtill conuerſation.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Who would not haue his wife ſo?

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Not he that himſelfe is not ſo: which is Marke
Anthony: he will to his Egyptian diſh againe: then ſhall
the ſighes of Oƈtauia blow the fire vp in Cæſar, and (as I
ſaid before) that which is the ſtrength of their Amity,
ſhall proue the immediate Author of their variance. An-
thony will vſe his affeƈtion where it is. Hee married but
his occaſion heere.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: And thus it may be. Come Sir, will you aboord?
I haue a health for you.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: I ſhall take it ſir: we haue vs’d our Throats in
Egypt.

speech.speaker: Men
speech.line: Come, let’s away.

scene.stagedir: Muſicke playes. Enter two or three Seruants with a Banket.

speech.line: Heere they’l be man: ſome o’th’their Plants are ill
rooted already, the leaſt winde i’th’world wil blow them
downe.
Lepidus is high Conlord.
They haue made him drinke Almes drinke.
As they pinch one another by the diſpoſition, hee
cries out, no more; reconciles them to his entreatie, and
himſelfe to’th’drinke.
But it raiſes the greater warre betweene him & his
diſcretion.
Why this it is to haue a name in great mens Fel-
lowſhip: I had as liue haue a Reede that will doe me no
ſeruice, as a Partizan I could not heaue.
To be call’d into a huge Sphere, and not to be ſeene
to moue in’t, are the holes where eyes ſhould bee, which
pittifully diſaſter the cheekes.

scene.stagedir: A Sennet ſounded. Enter Cæſar, Anthony, Pompey, Lepidus, Agrippa, Mecenas, Enobarbus, Menes, with other Captaines.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Thus do they Sir: they take the flow o’th’Nyle
By certaine ſcales i’th’Pyramid: they know
By’th’height, the lowneſſe, or the meane: If dearth
Or Foizon follow. The higher Nilus ſwels,
The more it promiſes: as it ebbes, the Seedſman
Vpon the ſlime and Ooze ſcatters his graine,
And ſhortly comes to Harueſt.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Y’haue ſtrange Serpents there?

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: I Lepidus.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Your Serpent of Egypt, is bred now of your mud
by the operation of your Sun: ſo is your Crocodile.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: They are ſo.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Sit, and ſome Wine: A health to Lepidus.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: I am not ſo well as I ſhould be:
But Ile ne’re out.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Not till you haue ſlept: I feare me you’l bee in
till then.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Nay certainly, I haue heard the Ptolomies Pyra-
miſis are very goodly things: without contradiƈtion I
haue heard that.

speech.speaker: Menas.
speech.line: Pompey, a word.

speech.speaker: Pomp.
speech.line: Say in mine eare, what is’t.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Forſake thy ſeate I do beſeech thee Captaine,
And heare me ſpeake a word.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Forbeare me till anon.
This Wine for Lepidus.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: What manner o’thing is your Crocodile?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: It is ſhap’d ſir like it ſelfe, and it is as broad as it
hath bredth; It is iuſt ſo high as it is, and mooues with it
owne organs. It liues by that which nouriſheth it, and
the Elements once out of it, it Tranſmigrates.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: What colour is it of?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Of it owne colour too.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: ’Tis a ſtrange Serpent.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: ’Tis ſo, and the teares of it are wet.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Will this deſcription ſatisfie him?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: With the Health that Pompey giues him, elſe he
is a very Epicure.

speech.speaker: Pomp.
speech.line: Go hang ſir, hang: tell me of that? Away:
Do as I bid you. Where’s this Cup I call’d for?

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: If for the ſake of Merit thou wilt heare mee,
Riſe from thy ſtoole.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: I thinke th’art mad: the matter?

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: I haue euer held my cap off to thy Fortunes.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Thou haſt ſeru’d me with much faith: what’s
elſe to ſay? Be iolly Lords.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Theſe Quicke-ſands Lepidus,
Keepe off, them for you ſinke.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Wilt thou be Lord of all the world?

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: What ſaiſt thou?

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Wilt thou be Lord of the whole world?
That’s twice.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: How ſhould that be?

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: But entertaine it, and though thou thinke me
poore, I am the man will giue thee all the world.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Haſt thou drunke well.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: No Pompey, I haue kept me from the cup,
Thou art if thou dar’ſt be, the earthly Ioue:
What ere the Ocean pales, or skie inclippes,
Is thine, if thou wilt ha’t.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Shew me which way?

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Theſe three World-ſharers, theſe Competitors
Are in thy veſſell. Let me cut the Cable,
And when we are put off, fall to their throates:
All there is thine.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Ah, this thou ſhouldſt haue done,
And not haue ſpoke on’t. In me ’tis villanie,
In thee, ’t had bin good ſeruice: thou muſt know,
’Tis not my profit that does lead mine Honour:
Mine Honour it, Repent that ere thy tongue,
Hath ſo betraide thine aƈte. Being done vnknowne,
I ſhould haue found it afterwards well done,
But muſt condemne it now: deſiſt, and drinke.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: For this, Ile neuer follow
Thy paul’d Fortunes more,
Who ſeekes and will not take, when once ’tis offer’d,
Shall neuer finde it more.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: This health to Lepidus.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Beare him aſhore,
Ile pledge it for him Pompey.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Heere’s to thee Menas.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Enobarbus, welcome.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Fill till the cup be hid.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: There’s a ſtrong Fellow Menas.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: A beares the third part of the world man: ſeeſt
not?

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: The third part, then he is drunk: would it were
all, that it might go on wheeles.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Drinke thou: encreaſe the Reeles.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Come.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: This is not yet an Alexandrian Feaſt.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: It ripen’s, towards it: ſtrike the Veſſells hoa.
Heere’s to Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: I could well forbear’t, it’s monſtrous labour
when I waſh my braine, and it grow fouler.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Be a Child o’th’time.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Poſſeſſe it, Ile make anſwer: but I had rather
faſt from all, foure dayes, then drinke ſo much in one.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Ha my braue Emperour, ſhall we daunce now
the Egyptian Backenals, and celebrate our drinke?

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Let’s ha’t good Souldier.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Come, let’s all take hands,
Till that the conquering Wine hath ſteep’t our ſenſe,
In ſoft and delicate Lethe.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: All take hands:
Make battery to our eares with the loud Muſicke,
The while, Ile place you, then the Boy ſhall ſing.
The holding euery man ſhall beate as loud,
As his ſtrong ſides can volly.
speech.stagedir: Muſicke Playes. Enobarbus places them hand in hand.
speech.line: Come thou Monarch of the Vine,
Plumpie Bacchus, with pinke eyne:
In thy Fattes our Cares be drown’d,
With thy Grapes our haires be Crown’d.
Cup vs till the world go round,
Cup vs till the world go round.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: What would you more?
Pompey goodnight. Good Brother
Let me requeſt you of our grauer buſineſſe
Frownes at this leuitie. Gentle Lords let’s part,
You ſee we haue burnt our cheekes. Strong Enobarbe
Is weaker then the Wine, and mine owne tongue
Spleet’s what it ſpeakes: the wilde diſguiſe hath almoſt
Antickt vs all. What needs more words? goodnight.
Good Anthony your hand.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Ile try you on the ſhore.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: And ſhall Sir, giues your hand.

speech.speaker: Pom.
speech.line: Oh Anthony, you haue my Father houſe.
But what, we are Friends?
Come downe into the Boate.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Take heed you fall not Menas: Ile not on ſhore,
No to my Cabin: theſe Drummes,
Theſe Trumpets, Flutes: what
Let Neptune heare, we bid aloud farewell
To theſe great Fellowes. Sound and be hang’d, ſound out.

speech.speaker: Enor.
speech.line: Hoo ſaies a there’s my Cap.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Hoa, Noble Captaine, come.

scene.stagedir: Enter Ventidius as it were in triumph, the dead body of Pacorus borne before him.

speech.speaker: Ven.
speech.line: Now darting Parthya art thou ſtroke, and now
Pleas’d Fortune does of Marcus Craſſus death
Make me reuenger. Beare the Kings Sonnes body,
Before our Army, thy Pacorus Orades,
Paies this for Marcus Craſſus.

speech.speaker: Romaine.
speech.line: Noble Ventidius,
Whil’ſt yet with Parthian blood thy Sword is warme,
The Fugitiue Parthians follow. Spurre through Media,
Meſapotamia, and the ſhelters, whether
The routed flie. So thy grand Captaine Anthony
Shall ſet thee on triumphant Chariots, and
Put Garlands on thy head.

speech.speaker: Ven.
speech.line: Oh Sillius, Sillius,
I haue done enough. A lower place note well
May make too great an aƈt. For learne this Sillius,
Better to leaue vndone, then by our deed
Acquire too high a Fame, when him we ſerues away.
Cæſar and Anthony, haue euer wonne
More in their officer, then perſon. Soſſius
One of my place in Syria, his Lieutenant,
For quicke accumulation of renowne,
Which he atchiu’d by’th’minute, loſt his fauour.
Who does i’th’Warres more then his Captaine can,
Becomes his Captaines Captaine: and Ambition
(The Souldiers vertue) rather makes choiſe of loſſe
Then gaine, which darkens him.
I could do more to do Anthonius good,
But ’twould offend him. And in his offence,
Should my performance periſh.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Thou haſt Ventidius that, without the which a
Souldier and his Sword graunts ſcarce diſtinƈtion: thou
wilt write to Anthony.

speech.speaker: Ven.
speech.line: Ile humbly ſignifie what in his name,
That magicall word of Warre we haue effeƈted,
How with his Banners, and his well paid ranks,
The nere-yet beaten Horſe of Parthia,
We haue iaded out o’th’Field.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Where is he now?

speech.speaker: Ven.
speech.line: He purpoſeth to Athens, whither with what haſt
The waight we muſt conuay with’s, will permit:
We ſhall appeare before him. On there, paſſe along.

scene.stagedir: Enter Agrippa at one doore, Enobarbus at another.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: What are the Brothers parted?

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: They haue diſpatcht with Pompey, he is gone,
The other three are Sealing. Oƈtauia weepes
To part from Rome: Cæſar is ſad, and Lepidus
Since Pompey’s feaſt, as Menas ſaies, is troubled
With the Greene-Sickneſſe.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: ’Tis a Noble Lepidus.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: A very fine one: oh, how he loues Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: Nay but how deerely he adores Mark Anthony.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Cæſar? why he’s the Iupiter of men.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: What’s Anthony, the God of Iupiter?

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Spake you of Cæſar? How, the non-pareill?

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: Oh Anthony, oh thou Arabian Bird!

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Would you praiſe Cæſar, ſay Cæſar go no further.

speech.speaker: Agr.
speech.line: Indeed he plied them both with excellent praiſes.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: But he loues Cæſar beſt, yet he loues Anthony:
Hoo, Hearts, Tongues, Figure,
Scribes, Bards, Poets, cannot
Thinke ſpeake, caſt, write, ſing, number: hoo,
His loue to Anthony. But as for Cæſar,
Kneele downe, kneele downe, and wonder.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: Both he loues.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: They are his Shards, and he their Beetle, ſo:
This is to horſe: Adieu, Noble Agrippa.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: Good Fortune worthy Souldier, and farewell.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cæſar, Anthony, Lepidus, and Oƈtauia.

speech.speaker: Antho.
speech.line: No further Sir.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: You take from me a great part of my ſelfe:
Vſe me well in’t. Siſter, proue ſuch a wife
As my thoughts make thee, and as my fartheſt Band
Shall paſſe on thy approofe: moſt Noble Anthony,
Let not the peece of Vertue which is ſet
Betwixt vs, as the Cyment of our loue
To keepe it builded, be the Ramme to batter
The Fortreſſe of it: for better might we
Haue lou’d without this meane, if on both parts
This be not cheriſht.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Make me not offended, in your diſtruſt.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: I haue ſaid.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: You ſhall not finde,
Though you be therein curious, the leſt cauſe
For what you ſeeme to feare, ſo the Gods keepe you,
And make the hearts of Romaines ſerue your ends:
We will heere part.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Farewell my deereſt Siſter, fare thee well,
The Elements be kind to thee, and make
Thy ſpirits all of comfort: fare thee well.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: My Noble Brother.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: The Aprill’s in her eyes, it is Loues ſpring,
And theſe the ſhowers to bring it on: be cheerfull.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Sir, looke well to my Husbands houſe: and —

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: What Oƈtauia?

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Ile tell you in your eare.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Her tongue will not obey her heart, nor can
Her heart informe her tongue.
The Swannes downe feather
That ſtands vpon the Swell at the full of Tide:
And neither way inclines.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Will Cæſar weepe?

speech.speaker: Agr.
speech.line: He ha’s a cloud in’s face.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: He were the worſe for that were he a Horſe, ſo is
he being a man.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: Why Enobarbus:
When Anthony found Iulius Cæſar dead,
He cried almoſt to roaring: And he wept,
When at Phillippi he found Brutus ſlaine.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: That year indeed, he was trobled with a rheume,
What willingly he did confound, he wail’d,
Beleeu’t till I weepe too.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: No ſweet Oƈtauia,
You ſhall heare from me ſtill: the time ſhall not
Out-go my thinking on you.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Come Sir, come,
Ile wraſtle with you in my ſtrength of loue,
Looke heere I haue you, thus I let you go,
And giue you to the Gods.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Adieu, be happy.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Let all the number of the Starres giue light
To thy faire way.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Farewell, farewell.

speech.speaker: Ant
speech.line: Farewell. Trumpets ſound. Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Alexas.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Where is the Fellow?

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Halfe afeard to come.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Go too, go too: Come hither Sir.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Good Maieſtie: Herod of Iury dare not looke
vpon you, but when you are well pleas’d.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: That Herods head, Ile haue: but how? When
Anthony is gone, through whom I might commaund it:
Come thou neere.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Moſt gratious Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Did’ſt thou behold Oƈtauia?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: I dread Queene.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Where?
