speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Madam in Rome, I lookt her in the face: and
ſaw her led betweene her Brother, and Marke Anthony.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Is ſhe as tall as me?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: She is not Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Didſt heare her ſpeake?
Is ſhe ſhrill tongu’d or low?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Madam, I heard her ſpeake, ſhe is low voic’d.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: That’s not ſo good: he cannot like her long.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Like her? Oh Iſis: ’tis impoſſible.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I thinke ſo Charmian: dull of tongue, & dwarfiſh
What Maieſtie is in her gate, remember
If ere thou look’ſt on Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: She creepes: her motion, & her ſtation are as one.
She ſhewes a body, rather then a life,
A Statue, then a Breather.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Is this certaine?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Or I haue no obſeruance.

speech.speaker: Cha.
speech.line: Three in Egypt cannot make better note.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: He’s very knowing, I do perceiu’t,
There’s nothing in her yet.
The Fellow ha’s good iudgement.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Excellent.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Gueſſe at her yeares, I prythee.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Madam, ſhe was a widdow.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Widdow? Charmian, hearke.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: And I do thinke ſhe’s thirtie.

speech.speaker: Cle.
speech.line: Bear’ſt thou her face in mind? is’t long or round?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Round, euen to faultineſſe.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: For the moſt part too, they are fooliſh that are
ſo. Her haire what colour?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Browne Madam: and her forehead
As low as ſhe would wiſh it.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: There’s Gold for thee,
Thou muſt not take my former ſharpeneſſe ill,
I will employ thee backe againe: I finde thee
Moſt fit for buſineſſe. Go, make thee ready,
Our Letters are prepar’d.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: A proper man.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Indeed he is ſo: I repent me much
That ſo I harried him. Why me think’s by him,
This Creature’s no ſuch thing.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Nothing Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: The man hath ſeene ſome Maieſty, and ſhould
know.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Hath he ſeene Maieſtie? Iſis elſe defend: and
ſeruing you ſo long.

speech.speaker: Cleopa.
speech.line: I haue one thing more to aske him yet good
Charmian: but ’tis no matter, thou ſhalt bring him to me
where I will write; all may be well enough.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: I warrant you Madam.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Nay, nay Oƈtauia, not onely that,
That were excuſable, that and thouſands more
Of ſemblable import, but he hath wag’d
New Warres ’gainſt Pompey. Made his will, and read it,
To publicke eare, ſpoke ſcantly of me,
When perforce he could not
But pay me tearmes of Honour: cold and ſickly
He vented then moſt narrow meaſure: lent me,
When the beſt hint was giuen him: he not took’t,
Or did it from his teeth.

speech.speaker: Oƈtaui.
speech.line: Oh my good Lord,
Beleeue not all, or if you muſt beleeue,
Stomacke not all. A more vnhappie Lady,
If this deuiſion chance, ne’re ſtood betweene
Praying for both parts:
The good Gods wil mocke me preſently,
When I ſhall pray: Oh bleſſe my Lord, and Husband,
Vndo that prayer, by crying out as loud,
Oh bleſſe my Brother. Husband winne, winne Brother,
Prayes, and diſtroyes the prayer, no midway
’Twixt theſe extreames at all.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Gentle Oƈtauia,
Let your beſt loue draw to that point which ſeeks
Beſt to preſerue it: if I looſe mine Honour,
I looſe my ſelfe: better I were not yours
Then your ſo branchleſſe. But as you requeſted,
Your ſelfe ſhall go between’s, the meane time Lady,
Ile raiſe the preparation of a Warre
Shall ſtaine your Brother, make your ſooneſt haſt,
So your deſires are yours.

speech.speaker: Oƈt.
speech.line: Thanks to my Lord,
The Ioue of power make me moſt weake, moſt weake,
Your reconciler: Warres ’twixt you twaine would be,
As if the world ſhould cleaue, and that ſlaine men
Should ſoalder vp the Rift.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: When it appeeres to you where this begins,
Turne your diſpleaſure that way, for our faults
Can neuer be ſo equall, that your loue
Can equally moue with them. Prouide your going,
Chooſe your owne company, and command what coſt
Your heart he’s mind too.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: How now Friend Eros?

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Ther’s ſtrange Newes come Sir.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: What man?

speech.speaker: Ero.
speech.line: Cæſar & Lepidus haue made warres vpon Pompey.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: This is old, what is the ſucceſſe?

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Cæſar hauing made vſe of him in the warres
’gainſt Pompey: preſently denied him riuality, would not
let him partake in the glory of the aƈtion, and not reſting
here, accuſes him of Letters he had formerly wrote to
Pompey. Vpon his owne appeale ſeizes him, ſo the poore
third is vp, till death enlarge his Confine.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Then would thou hadſt a paire of chaps no more,
and throw betweene them all the food thou haſt, they’le
grinde the other. Where’s Anthony?

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: He’s walking in the garden thus, and ſpurnes
The ruſh that lies before him. Cries Foole Lepidus,
And threats the throate of that his Officer,
That murdred Pompey.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Our great Nauies rig’d.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: For Italy and Cæſar, more Domitius,
My Lord deſires you preſently: my Newes
I might haue told heareafter.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: ’Twillbe naught, but let it be: bring me to Anthony.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Come Sir,

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Contemning Rome he ha’s done all this, & more
In Alexandria: heere’s the manner of’t:
I’th’Market-place on a Tribunall ſiluer’d,
Cleopatra and himſelfe in Chaires of Gold
Were publikely enthron’d: at the feet, ſat
Cæſarion whom they call my Fathers Sonne,
And all the vnlawfull iſſue, that their Luſt
Since then hath made betweene them. Vnto her,
He gaue the ſtabliſhment of Egypt, made her
Of lower Syria, Cyprus, Lydia, abſolute Queene.

speech.speaker: Mece.
speech.line: This in the publike eye?

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: I’th’common ſhew place, where they exerciſe,
His Sonnes hither proclaimed the King of Kings,
Great Media, Parthia, and Armenia
He gaue to Alexander. To Ptolomy he aſſign’d,
Syria, Silicia, and Phœnetia: ſhe
In th’abiliments of the Goddeſſe Iſis
That day appeer’d, and oft before gaue audience,
As ’tis reported ſo.

speech.speaker: Mece.
speech.line: Let Rome be thus inform’d.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: Who queazie with his inſolence already,
Will their good thoughts call from him.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: The people knowes it,
And haue now receiu’d his accuſations.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: Who does he accuſe?

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Cæſar, and that hauing in Cicilie
Sextus Pompeius ſpoil’d, we had not rated him
His part o’th’Iſle. Then does he ſay, he lent me
Some ſhipping vnreſtor’d. Laſtly, he frets
That Lepidus of the Triumpherate, ſhould be depos’d,
And being that, we detaine all his Reuenue.

speech.speaker: Agri.
speech.line: Sir, this ſhould be anſwer’d.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: ’Tis done already, and the Meſſenger gone:
I haue told him Lepidus was growne too cruell,
That he his high Authority abus’d,
And did deſerue his change: for what I haue conquer’d,
I grant him part: but then in his Armenia,
And other of his conquer’d Kingdoms, I demand the like

speech.speaker: Mec.
speech.line: Hee’l neuer yeeld to that.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Nor muſt not then be yeelded to in this.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Haile Cæſar, and my L. haile moſt deere Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: That euer I ſhould call thee Caſt-away.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: You haue not call’d me ſo, nor haue you cauſe.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Why haue you ſtoln vpon vs thus? you come not
Like Cæſars Siſter, The wife of Anthony
Should haue an Army for an Vſher, and
The neighes of Horſe to tell of her approach,
Long ere ſhe did appeare. The trees by’th’way
Should haue borne men, and expeƈtation fainted,
Longing for what it had not. Nay, the duſt
Should haue aſcended to the Roofe of Heauen,
Rais’d by your populous Troopes: But you are come
A Market-maid to Rome, and haue preuented
The oſtentation of our loue; which left vnshewne,
Is often left vnlou’d: we ſhould haue met you
By Sea, and Land, ſupplying euery Stage
With an augmented greeting.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Good my Lord,
To come thus was I not conſtrain’d, but did it
On my free-will. My Lord Marke Anthony,
Hearing that you prepar’d for Warre, acquainted
My greeued eare withall: whereon I begg’d
His pardon for returne.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Which ſoone he granted,
Being an abſtraƈt ’tweene his Luſt, and him.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Do not ſay ſo, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: I haue eyes vpon him,
And his affaires come to me on the wind: wher is he now?

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: My Lord, in Athens.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: No my moſt wronged Siſter, Cleopatra
Hath nodded him to her. He hath giuen his Empire
Vp to a Whore, who now are leuying
The Kings o’th’earth for Warre. He hath aſſembled,
Bochus the King of Lybia, Archilaus
Of Cappadocia, Philadelphos King
Of Paphlagonia: the Thracian King Adullas,
King Manchus of Arabia, King of Pont,
Herod of Iewry, Mithridates King
Of Comageat, Polemen and Amintas,
The Kings of Mede, and Licoania,
With a more larger Liſt of Scepters.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Aye me moſt wretched,
That haue my heart parted betwixt two Friends,
That does affliƈt each other.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Welcom hither: your Letters did with-holde our breaking forth
Till we perceiu’d both how you were wrong led,
And we in negligent danger: cheere your heart,
Be you not troubled with the time, which driues
O’re your content, theſe ſtrong neceſſities,
But let determin’d things to deſtinie
Hold vnbewayl’d their way. Welcome to Rome,
Nothing more deere to me: You are abus’d
Beyond the marke of thought: and the high Gods
To do you Iuſtice, makes his Miniſters
Of vs, and thoſe that loue you. Beſt of comfort,
And euer welcom to vs.

speech.speaker: Agrip.
speech.line: Welcome Lady.

speech.speaker: Mec.
speech.line: Welcome deere Madam,
Each heart in Rome does loue and pitty you,
Onely th’adulterous Anthony, moſt large
In his abhominations, turnes you off,
And giues his potent Regiment to a Trull
That noyſes it againſt vs.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Is it ſo ſir?

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Moſt certaine: Siſter welcome: pray you
Be euer knowne to patience. My deer’ſt Siſter.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I will be euen with thee, doubt it not.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: But why, why, why?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Thou haſt foreſpoke my being in theſe warres,
And ſay’ſt it it not fit.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Well: is it, is it.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: If not, denounc’d againſt vs, why ſhould not
we be there in perſon.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Well, I could reply: if wee ſhould ſerue with
Horſe and Mares together, the Horſe were meerly loſt:
the Mares would beare a Soldiour and his Horſe.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: What is’t you ſay?

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Your preſence needs muſt puzle Anthony,
Take from his heart, take from his Braine, from’s time,
What ſhould not then be ſpar’d. He is already
Traduc’d for Leuity, and ’tis ſaid in Rome,
That Photinus an Eunuch, and your Maides
Mannage this warre.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Sinke Rome, and their tongues rot
That ſpeake againſt vs. A Charge we beare i’th’Warre,
And as the preſident of my Kingdome will
Appeare there for a man. Speake not againſt it,
I will not ſtay behinde.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Nay I haue done, here comes the Emperor.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Is it not ſtrange Camidius,
That from Tarientum, and Branduſium,
He could ſo quickly cut the Ionian Sea,
And take in Troine. You haue heard on’t (Sweet?)

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Celerity is neuer more admir’d,
Then by the negligent.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: A good rebuke,
Which might haue well becom’d the beſt of men
To taunt at ſlackneſſe. Camidius, wee
Will fight with him by Sea.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: By Sea, what elſe?

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Why will my Lord, do ſo?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: For that he dares vs too’t.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: So hath my Lord, dar’d him to ſingle fight.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: I, and to wage this Battell at Pharſalia,
Where Cæſar fought with Pompey. But theſe offers
Which ſerue not for his vantage, he ſhakes off,
And ſo ſhould you.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Your Shippes are not well mann’d,
Your Marriners are Militers, Reapers, people
Ingroſt by ſwift Impreſſe. In Cæſars Fleete,
Are thoſe, that often haue ’gainſt Pompey fought,
Their ſhippes are yare, yours heauy: no diſgrace
Shall fall you for refuſing him at Sea,
Being prepar’d for Land.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: By Sea, by Sea.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Moſt worthy Sir, you therein throw away
The abſolute Soldierſhip you haue by Land,
Diſtraƈt your Armie, which doth moſt conſiſt
Of Warre-markt-footmen, leaue vnexecuted
Your owne renowned knowledge, quite forgoe
The way which promiſes aſſurance, and
Giue vp your ſelfe meerly to chance and hazard,
From firme Securitie.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Ile fight at Sea.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I haue ſixty Sailes, Cæſar none better.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Our ouer-plus of ſhipping will we burne,
And with the reſt full mann’d, from th’head of Aƈtion
Beate th’approaching Cæſar. But if we faile,
We then can doo’t at Land.
Thy Buſineſſe?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: The Newes is true, my Lord, he is deſcried,
Cæſar ha’s taken Toryne.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Can he be there in perſon? ’Tis impoſſible
Strange, that his power ſhould be. Camidius,
Our nineteene Legions thou ſhalt hold by Land,
And our twelue thouſand Horſe. Wee’l to our Ship,
Away my Thetis.
How now worthy Souldier?

speech.speaker: Soul.
speech.line: Oh Noble Emperor, do not fight by Sea,
Truſt not to rotten plankes: Do you miſdoubt
This Sword, and theſe my Wounds; let th’Egyptians
And the Phœnicians go a ducking: wee
Haue vs’d to conquer ſtanding on the earth,
And fighting foot to foot.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Well, well, away.

speech.speaker: Soul.
speech.line: By Hercules I thinke I am i’th’right.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Souldier thou art: but his whole aƈtion growes
Not in the power on’t: ſo our Leaders leade,
And we are Womens men.

speech.speaker: Soul.
speech.line: You keepe by Land the Legions and the Horſe
whole, do you not?

speech.speaker: Ven.
speech.line: Marcus Oƈtauius, Marcus Iusteus,
Publicola, and Celius, are for Sea:
But we keepe whole by Land. This ſpeede of Cæſars
Carries beyond beleefe.

speech.speaker: Soul.
speech.line: While he was yet in Rome,
His power went out in ſuch diſtraƈtions,
As beguilde all Spies.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Who’s his Lieutenant, heare you?

speech.speaker: Soul.
speech.line: They ſay, one Towrus.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Well, I know the man.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: The Emperor cals Camidius.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: With Newes the times with Labour,
And throwes forth each minute, ſome.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cæſar with his Army, marching.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Towrus?

speech.speaker: Tow.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Strike not by Land,
Keepe whole, prouoke not Battaile
Till we haue done at Sea. Do not exceede
The Preſcript of this Scroule: Our fortune lyes
Vpon this iumpe. exit.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Set we our Squadrons on yond ſide o’th’Hill,
In eye of Cæſars battaile, from which place
We may the number of the Ships behold,
And ſo proceed accordingly.

scene.stagedir: Camidius Marcheth with his Land Army one way ouer the ſtage, and Towrus the Lieutenant of Cæſar the other way: After their going in, is heard the noiſe of a Sea fight. Alarum. Enter Enobarbus and Scarus.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Naught, naught, al naught, I can behold no longer:
Thantoniad, the Egyptian Admirall,
With all their ſixty flye, and turne the Rudder:
To ſee’t, mine eyes are blaſted.

speech.speaker: Scar.
speech.line: Gods, & Goddeſſes, all the whol ſynod of them!

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: What’s thy paſſion.

speech.speaker: Scar.
speech.line: The greater Cantle of the world, is loſt
With very ignorance, we haue kiſt away
Kingdomes, and Prouinces.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: How appeares the Fight?

speech.speaker: Scar.
speech.line: On our ſide, like the Token’d Peſtilence,
Where death is ſure. Yon ribaudred Nagge of Egypt,
(Whom Leproſie o’re-take) i’th’midſt o’th’fight,
When vantage like a payre of Twinnes appear’d
Both as the ſame, or rather ours the elder;
(The Breeze vpon her) like a Cow in Inne,
Hoiſts Sailes, and flyes.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: That I beheld:
Mine eyes did ſicken at the ſight, and could not
Indure a further view.

speech.speaker: Scar.
speech.line: She once being looft,
The Noble ruine of her Magicke, Anthony,
Claps on his Sea-wing, and (like a doting Mallard)
Leauing the Fight in heighth, flyes after her:
I neuer ſaw an Aƈtion of ſuch ſhame;
Experience, Man-hood, Honor, ne’re before,
Did violate ſo it ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Alacke, alacke.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Our Fortune on the Sea is out of breath,
And ſinkes moſt lamentably. Had our Generall
Bin what he knew himſelfe, it had gone well:
Oh his ha’s giuen example for our flight,
Moſt groſſely by his owne.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: I, are you thereabouts? Why then goodnight
indeede.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Toward Peloponneſus are they fled.

speech.speaker: Scar.
speech.line: ’Tis eaſie toot,
And there I will attend what further comes.

speech.speaker: Camid.
speech.line: To Cæſar will I render
My Legions and my Horſe, ſixe Kings alreadie
Shew me the way of yeelding.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Ile yet follow
The wounded chance of Anthony, though my reaſon
Sits in the winde againſt me.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Hearke, the Land bids me tread no more vpon’t,
It is aſham’d to beare me. Friends, come hither,
I am ſo lated in the world, that I
Haue loſt my way for euer. I haue a ſhippe,
Laden with Gold, take that, diuide it: flye,
And make your peace with Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Omnes.
speech.line: Fly? Not wee.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I haue fled my ſelfe, and haue inſtruƈted cowards
To runne, and ſhew their ſhoulders. Friends be gone,
I haue my ſelfe reſolu’d vpon a courſe,
Which has no neede of you. Be gone,
My Treaſure’s in the Harbour. Take it: Oh,
I follow’d that I bluſh to looke vpon,
My very haires do mutiny: for the white
Reproue the browne for raſhneſſe, and they them
For feare, and doting. Friends be gone, you ſhall
Haue Letters from me to ſome Friends, that will
Sweepe your way for you. Pray you looke not ſad,
Nor make replyes of loathneſſe, take the hint
Which my diſpaire proclaimes. Let them be left
Which leaues it ſelfe, to the Sea-ſide ſtraight way;
I will poſſeſſe you of that ſhip and Treaſure.
Leaue me, I pray a little: pray you now,
Nay do ſo: for indeede I haue loſt command,
Therefore I pray you, Ile ſee you by and by.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cleopatra led by Charmian and Eros.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Nay gentle Madam, to him, comfort him.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: Do moſt deere Queene.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Do, why, what elſe?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Let me ſit downe: Oh Iuno.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: No, no, no, no, no.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: See you heere, Sir?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Oh fie, fie, fie.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Madam.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: Madam, oh good Empreſſe.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Sir, ſir.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Yes my Lord, yes; he at Philippi kept
His ſword e’ne like a dancer, while I ſtrooke
The leane and wrinkled Caſſius, and ’twas I
That the mad Brutus ended: he alone
Dealt on Lieutenantry, and no praƈtiſe had
In the braue ſquares of Warre: yet now: no matter.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Ah ſtand by.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: The Queene my Lord, the Queene.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: Go to him, Madam, ſpeake to him,
Hee’s vnqualitied with very ſhame.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Well then, ſuſtaine me: Oh.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Moſt Noble Sir ariſe, the Queene approaches,
Her head’s declin’d, and death will ceaſe her, but
Your comfort makes the reſcue.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I haue offended Reputation,
A moſt vnnoble ſweruing.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Sir, the Queene.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Oh whether haſt thou lead me Egypt, ſee
How I conuey my ſhame, out of thine eyes,
By looking backe what I haue left behinde
Stroy’d in diſhonor.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Oh my Lord, my Lord,
Forgiue my fearfull ſayles, I little thought
You would haue followed.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Egypt, thou knew’ſt too well,
My heart was to thy Rudder tyed by’th’ſtrings,
And thou ſhould’ſt ſtowe me after. O’re my ſpirit
The full ſupremacie thou knew’ſt, and that
Thy becke, might from the bidding of the Gods
Command mee.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Oh my pardon.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Now I muſt
To the young man ſend humble Treaties, dodge
And palter in the ſhifts of lownes, who
With halfe the bulke o’th’world plaid as I pleas’d,
Making, and marring Fortunes. You did know
How much you were my Conqueror, and that
My Sword, made weake by my affeƈtion, would
Obey it on all cauſe.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Pardon, pardon.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Fall not a teare I ſay, one of them rates
All that is wonne and loſt: Giue me a kiſſe,
Euen this repayes me.
We ſent our Schoolemaſter, is a come backe?
Loue I am full of Lead: ſome Wine
Within there, and our Viands: Fortune knowes,
We ſcorne her moſt, when moſt ſhe offers blowes.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cæſar, Agrippa, and Dollabello, with others.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Let him appeare that’s come from Anthony.
Know you him.

speech.speaker: Dolla.
speech.line: Cæſar, ’tis his Schoolemaſter,
An argument that he is pluckt, when hither
He ſends ſo poore a Pinnion of his Wing,
Which had ſuperfluous Kings for Meſſengers,
Not many Moones gone by.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Approach, and ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Amb.
speech.line: Such as I am, I come from Anthony:
I was of late as petty to his ends,
As is the Morne-dew on the Mertle leafe
To his grand Sea.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Bee’t ſo, declare thine office.

speech.speaker: Amb.
speech.line: Lord of his Fortunes he ſalutes thee, and
Requires to liue in Egypt, which not granted
He Leſſons his Requeſts, and to thee ſues
To let him breath betweene the Heauens and Earth
A priuate man in Athens: this for him.
Next, Cleopatra does confeſſe thy Greatneſſe,
Submits her to thy might, and of thee craues
The Circle of the Ptolomies for her heyres,
Now hazarded to thy Grace.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: For Anthony,
I haue no eares to his requeſt. The Queene,
Of Audience, nor Deſire ſhall faile, ſo ſhee
From Egypt driue her all-diſgraced Friend,
Or take his life there. This if ſhee performe,
She ſhall not ſue vnheard. So to them both.

speech.speaker: Amb.
speech.line: Fortune purſue thee.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Bring him through the Bands:
To try thy Eloquence, now ’tis time, diſpatch,
From Anthony winne Cleopatra, promiſe
And in our Name, what ſhe requires, adde more
From thine inuention, offers. Women are not
In their beſt Fortunes ſtrong; but want will periure
The ne’re touch’d Veſtall. Try thy cunning Thidias,
Make thine owne Ediƈt for thy paines, which we
Will anſwer as a Law.

speech.speaker: Thid.
speech.line: Cæſar. I go.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Obſerue how Anthony becomes his flaw,
And what thou think’ſt his very aƈtion ſpeakes
In euery power that mooues.

speech.speaker: Thid.
speech.line: Cæſar, I ſhall.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: What ſhall we do, Enobarbus?

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Thinke, and dye.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Is Anthony, or we in fault for this?

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Anthony onely, that would make his will
Lord of his Reaſon. What though you fled,
From that great face of Warre, whoſe ſeuerall ranges
Frighted each other? Why ſhould he follow?
The itch of his Affeƈtion ſhould not then
Haue nickt his Captain-ſhip, at ſuch a point,
When halfe to halfe the world oppos’d, he being
The meered queſtion? ’Twas a ſhame no leſſe
Then was his loſſe, to courſe your flying Flagges,
And leaue his Nauy gazing.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Prythee peace.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Is that his anſwer?

speech.speaker: Amb.
speech.line: I my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: The Queene ſhall then haue courteſie,
So ſhe will yeeld vs vp.

speech.speaker: Am.
speech.line: He ſayes ſo.

speech.speaker: Antho.
speech.line: Let her know’t. To the Boy Cæſar ſend this
grizled head, and he will fill thy wiſhes to the brimme,
With Principalities.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: That head my Lord?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: To him againe, tell him he weares the Roſe
Of youth vpon him: from which, the world ſhould note
Something particular: His Coine, Ships, Legions,
May be a Cowards, whoſe Miniſters would preuaile
Vnder the ſeruice of a Childe, as ſoone
As i’th’Command of Cæſar. I dare him therefore
To lay his gay Compariſons a-part,
And anſwer me declin’d, Sword againſt Sword,
Our ſelues alone: Ile write it: Follow me.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Yes like enough: hye battel’d Cæſar will
Vnſtate his happineſſe, and be Stag’d to’th’ſhew
Againſt a Sworder. I ſee mens Iudgements are
A parcell of their Fortunes, and things outward
Do draw the inward quality after them
To ſuffer all alike, that he ſhould dreame,
Knowing all meaſures, the full Cæſar will
Anſwer his emptineſſe; Cæſar thou haſt ſubdu’de
His iudgement too.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: A Meſſenger from Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: What no more Ceremony? See my Women,
Againſt the blowne Roſe may they ſtop their noſe,
That kneel’d vnto the Buds. Admit him ſir.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Mine honeſty, and I, beginne to ſquare,
The Loyalty well held to Fooles, does make
Our Faith meere folly: yet he that can endure
To follow with Allegeance a falne Lord,
Does conquer him that did his Maſter conquer,
And earnes a place i’th’Story.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Cæſars will.

speech.speaker: Thid.
speech.line: Heare it apart.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: None but Friends: ſay boldly.

speech.speaker: Thid.
speech.line: So haply are they Friends to Anthony.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: He needs as many (Sir) as Cæſar ha’s,
Or needs not vs. If Cæſar pleaſe, our Maſter
Will leape to be his Friend: For vs you know,
Whoſe he is, we are, and that is Cæſars.

speech.speaker: Thid.
speech.line: So. Thus then thou moſt renown’d, Cæſar intreats,
Not to conſider in what caſe thou ſtand’ſt
Further then he is Cæſars.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Go on, right Royall.

speech.speaker: Thid.
speech.line: He knowes that you embrace not Anthony
As you did loue, but as you feared him.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Oh.

speech.speaker: Thid.
speech.line: The ſcarre’s vpon your Honor, therefore he
Does pitty, as conſtrained blemiſhes,
Not as deſerued.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: He is a God,
And knowes what is moſt right. Mine Honour
Was not yeelded, but conquer’d meerely.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: To be ſure of that, I will aske Anthony.
Sir, ſir, thou art ſo leakie
That we muſt leaue thee to thy ſinking, for
Thy deereſt quit thee.

speech.speaker: Thid.
speech.line: Shall I ſay to Cæſar,
What you require of him: for he partly begges
To be deſir’d to giue. It much would pleaſe him,
That of his Fortunes you ſhould make a ſtaffe
To leane vpon. But it would warme his ſpirits
To heare from me you had left Anthony,
And put your ſelfe vnder his ſhrowd, the vniuerſal Landlord.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: What’s your name?

speech.speaker: Thid.
speech.line: My name is Thidias.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Moſt kinde Meſſenger,
Say to great Cæſar this in diſputation,
I kiſſe his conqu’ring hand: Tell him, I am prompt
To lay my Crowne at’s feete, and there to kneele.
Tell him, from his all-obeying breath, I heare
The doome of Egypt.

speech.speaker: Thid.
speech.line: ’Tis your Nobleſt courſe:
Wiſedome and Fortune combatting together,
If that the former dare but what it can,
No chance may ſhake it. Giue me grace to lay
My dutie on your hand.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Your Cæſars Father oft,
(When he hath mus’d of taking kingdomes in)
Beſtow’d his lips on that vnworthy place,
As it rain’d kiſſes.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Fauours? By Ioue that thunders. What art thou Fellow?

speech.speaker: Thid.
speech.line: One that but performes
The bidding of the fulleſt man, and worthieſt
To haue command obey’d.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: You will be whipt.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Approch there: ah you Kite. Now Gods & diuels
Authority melts from me of late. When I cried hoa,
Like Boyes vnto a muſſe, Kings would ſtart forth,
And cry, your will. Haue you no eares?
I am Anthony yet. Take hence this Iack, and whip him.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: ’Tis better playing with a Lions whelpe,
Then with an old one dying.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Moone and Starres,
Whip him: wer’t twenty of the greateſt Tributaries
That do acknowledge Cæſar, ſhould I finde them
So ſawcy with the hand of ſhe heere, what’s her name
Since ſhe was Cleopatra? Whip him Fellowes,
Till like a Boy you ſee him crindge his face,
And whine aloud for mercy. Take him hence.

speech.speaker: Thid.
speech.line: Marke Anthony.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Tugge him away: being whipt
Bring him againe, the Iacke of Cæſars ſhall
Beare vs an arrant to him.
You were halfe blaſted ere I knew you: Ha?
Haue I my pillow left vnpreſt in Rome,
Forborne the getting of a lawfull Race,
And by a Iem of women, to be abus’d
By one that lookes on Feeders?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Good my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: You haue beene a boggeler euer,
But when we in our viciouſneſſe grow hard
(Oh miſery on’t) the wiſe Gods ſeele our eyes
In our owne filth, drop our cleare iudgements, make vs
Adore our errors, laugh at’s while we ſtrut
To our confuſion.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Oh, is’t come to this?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I found you as a Morſell, cold vpon
Dead Cæſars Trencher: Nay, you were a Fragment
Of Gneius Pompeyes, beſides what hotter houres
Vnregiſtred in vulgar Fame, you haue
Luxuriouſly pickt out. For I am ſure,
Though you can gueſſe what Temperance ſhould be,
You know not what it is.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Wherefore is this?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: To let a Fellow that will take rewards,
And ſay, God quit you, be familiar with
My play-fellow, your hand; this Kingly Seale,
And plighter of high hearts. O that I were
Vpon the hill of Baſan, to out-roare
The horned Heard, for I haue ſauage cauſe,
And to proclaime it ciuilly, were like
A halter’d necke, which do’s the Hangman thanke,
For being yare about him. Is he whipt?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Soundly, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Cried he? and begg’d a Pardon?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: He did aske fauour.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: If that thy Father liue, let him repent
Thou was’t not made his daughter, and be thou ſorrie
To follow Cæſar in his Triumph, ſince
Thou haſt bin whipt. For following him, henceforth
The white hand of a Lady Feauer thee,
Shake thou to looke on’t. Get thee backe to Cæſar,
Tell him thy entertainment: looke thou ſay
He makes me angry with him. For he ſeemes
Proud and diſdainfull, harping on what I am,
Not what he knew I was. He makes me angry,
And at this time moſt eaſie ’tis to doo’t:
When my good Starres, that were my former guides
Haue empty left their Orbes, and ſhot their Fires
Into th’Abiſme of hell. If he miſlike,
My ſpeech, and what is done, tell him he has
Hiparchus, my enfranched Bondman, whom
He may at pleaſure whip, or hang, or torture,
As he ſhall like to quit me. Vrge it thou:
Hence with thy ſtripes, be gone.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Haue you done yet?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Alacke our Terrene Moone is now Eclipſt,
And it portends alone the fall of Anthony.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I muſt ſtay his time?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: To flatter Cæſar, would you mingle eyes
With one that tyes his points.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Not know me yet?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Cold-hearted toward me?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Ah (Deere) if I be ſo,
From my cold heart let Heauen ingender haile,
And poyſon it in the ſourſe, and the firſt ſtone
Drop in my necke: as it determines ſo
Diſſolue my life, the next Cæſarian ſmile,
Till by degrees the memory of my wombe,
Together with my braue Egyptians all,
By the diſcandering of this pelleted ſtorme,
Lye graueleſſe, till the Flies and Gnats of Nyle
Haue buried them for prey.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I am ſatisfied:
Cæſar ſets downe in Alexandria, where
I will oppoſe his Fate. Our force by Land,
Hath Nobly held, our ſeuer’d Nauie too
Haue knit againe, and Fleete, threatning moſt Sea-like.
Where haſt thou bin my heart? Doſt thou heare Lady?
If from the Field I ſhall returne once more
To kiſſe theſe Lips, I will appeare in Blood,
I, and my Sword, will earne our Chronicle,
There’s hope in’t yet.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: That’s my braue Lord.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I will be trebble-sinewed, hearted, breath’d,
And fight maliciouſly: for when mine houres
Were nice and lucky, men did ranſome liues
Of me for ieſts: But now, Ile ſet my teeth,
And ſend to darkeneſſe all that ſtop me. Come,
Let’s haue one other gawdy night: Call to me
All my ſad Captaines, fill our Bowles once more:
Let’s mocke the midnight Bell.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: It is my Birth-day,
I had thought t’haue held it poore. But ſince my Lord
Is Anthony againe, I will be Cleopatra.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: We will yet do well.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Call all his Noble Captaines to my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Do ſo, wee’l ſpeake to them,
And to night Ile force
The Wine peepe through their ſcarres.
Come on (my Queene)
There’s ſap in’t yet. The next time I do fight
Ile make death loue me: for I will contend
Euen with his peſtilent Sythe.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Now hee’l out-ſtare the Lightning, to be furious
Is to be frighted out of feare, and in that moode
The Doue will pecke the Eſtridge; and I ſee ſtill
A diminution in our Captaines braine,
Reſtores his heart; when valour prayes in reaſon,
It eates the Sword it fights with: I will ſeeke
Some way to leaue him.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cæſar, Agrippa, & Mecenas with his Army, Cæſar reading a Letter.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: He calles me Boy, and chides as he had power
To beate me out of Egypt. My Meſſenger
He hath whipt with Rods, dares me to perſonal Combat.
Cæſar to Anthony: let the old Ruffian know,
I haue many other wayes to dye: meane time
Laugh at his Challenge.

speech.speaker: Mece.
speech.line: Cæſar muſt thinke,
When one ſo great begins to rage, hee’s hunted
Euen to falling. Giue him no breath, but now
Make boote of his diſtraƈtion: Neuer anger
Made good guard for it ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Let our beſt heads know,
That to morrow, the laſt of many Battailes
We meane to fight. Within our Files there are,
Of thoſe that ſeru’d Marke Anthony but late,
Enough to fetch him in. See it done,
And Feaſt the Army, we haue ſtore to doo’t,
And they haue earn’d the waſte. Poore Anthony.

scene.stagedir: Enter Anthony, Cleopatra, Enobarbus, Charmian, Iras, Alexas, with others.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: He will not fight with me, Domitian?

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: No?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Why ſhould he not?

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune,
He is twenty men to one.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: To morrow Soldier,
By Sea and Land Ile fight: or I will liue,
Or bathe my dying Honor in the blood
Shall make it liue againe. Woo’t thou fight well.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: Ile ſtrike, and cry, Take all.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Well ſaid, come on:
Call forth my Houſhold Seruants, lets to night
Be bounteous at our Meale. Giue me thy hand,
Thou haſt bin rightly honeſt, ſo haſt thou,
Thou, and thou, and thou: you haue ſeru’d me well,
And Kings haue beene your fellowes.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: What meanes this?

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: ’Tis one of thoſe odde tricks which ſorow ſhoots
Out of the minde.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: And thou art honeſt too:
I wiſh I could be made ſo many men,
And all of you clapt vp together, in
An Anthony: that I might do you ſeruice,
So good as you haue done.

speech.speaker: Omnes.
speech.line: The Gods forbid.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Well, my good Fellowes, wait on me to night:
Scant not my Cups, and make as much of me,
As when mine Empire was your Fellow too,
And ſuffer’d my command.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: What does he meane?

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: To make his Followers weepe.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Tend me to night;
May be, it is the period of your duty,
Haply you ſhall not ſee me more, or if,
A mangled ſhadow. Perchance to morrow,
You’l ſerue another Maſter. I looke on you,
As one that takes his leaue. Mine honeſt Friends,
I turne you not away, but like a Maſter
Married to your good ſeruice, ſtay till death:
Tend me to night two houres, I aske no more,
And the Gods yeeld you for’t.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: What meane you (Sir)
To giue them this diſcomfort? Looke they weepe,
And I an Aſſe, am Onyon-ey’d; for ſhame,
Transforme vs not to women.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Ho, ho, ho:
Now the Witch take me, if I meant it thus.
Grace grow where thoſe drops fall (my hearty Friends)
You take me in too dolorous a ſenſe,
For I ſpake to you for your comfort, did deſire you
To burne this night with Torches: Know (my hearts)
I hope well of to morrow, and will leade you,
Where rather Ile expeƈt viƈtorious life,
Then death, and Honor. Let’s to Supper, come,
And drowne conſideration.

speech.speaker: 1. Sol.
speech.line: Brother, goodnight: to morrow is the day.

speech.speaker: 2. Sol.
speech.line: It will determine one way: Fare you well.
Heard you of nothing ſtrange about the ſtreets.
Nothing: what newes?
Belike ’tis but a Rumour, good night to you.
Well ſir, good night.
Souldiers, haue carefull Watch.
And you: Goodnight, goodnight.

scene.stagedir: They place themſelues in euery corner of the Stage.

speech.line: Heere we: and if to morrow
Our Nauie thriue, I haue an abſolute hope
Our Landmen will ſtand vp.
’Tis a braue Army, and full of purpoſe.

scene.stagedir: Muſicke of the Hoboyes is vnder the Stage.

speech.line: Peace, what noiſe?
Liſt, liſt.
Hearke.
Muſicke i’th’ Ayre.
Vnder the earth.
It ſignes well, do’s it not?
No.
Peace I ſay: What ſhould this meane?
’Tis the God Hercules, whom Anthony loued,
Now leaues him.
Walke, let’s ſee if other Watchmen
Do heare what we do?
How now Maiſters? Speak together.

speech.speaker: Omnes.
speech.line: How now? how now? do you heare this?
I, is’t not ſtrange?
Do you heare Maſters? Do you heare?
Follow the noyſe ſo farre as we haue quarter.
Let’s ſee how it will giue off.

speech.speaker: Omnes.
speech.line: Content: ’Tis ſtrange.

scene.stagedir: Enter Anthony and Cleopatra, with others.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Eros, mine Armour Eros.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Sleepe a little.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: No my Chucke. Eros, come mine Armor Eros.
Come good Fellow, put thine Iron on,
If Fortune be not ours to day, it is
Becauſe we braue her. Come.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Nay, Ile helpe too, Anthony.
What’s this for? Ah let be, let be, thou art
The Armourer of my heart: Falſe, falſe: This, this,
Sooth-law Ile helpe: Thus it muſt bee.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Well, well, we ſhall thriue now.
Seeſt thou my good Fellow. Go, put on thy defences.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Briefely Sir.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Is not this buckled well?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Rarely, rarely:
He that vnbuckles this, till we do pleaſe
To daft for our Repoſe, ſhall heare a ſtorme.
Thou fumbleſt Eros, and my Queenes a Squire
More tight at this, then thou: Diſpatch. O Loue,
That thou couldſt ſee my Warres to day, and knew’ſt
The Royall Occupation, thou ſhould’ſt ſee
A Workeman in’t.
Good morrow to thee, welcome,
Thou look’ſt like him that knowes a warlike Charge:
To buſineſſe that we loue, we riſe betime,
And go too’t with delight.

speech.speaker: Soul.
speech.line: A thouſand Sir, early though’t be, haue on their
Riueted trim, and at the Port expeƈt you.

scene.stagedir: Showt. Trumpets Flouriſh. Enter Captaines, and Souldiers.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: The Morne is faire: Good morrow Generall.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Good morrow Generall.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: ’Tis well blowne Lads.
This Morning, like the ſpirit of a youth
That meanes to be of note, begins betimes.
So, ſo: Come giue me that, this way, well-ſed.
Fare thee well Dame, what ere becomes of me,
This is a Soldiers kiſſe: rebukeable,
And worthy ſhamefull checke it were, to ſtand
On more Mechanicke Complement, Ile leaue thee.
Now like a man of Steele, you that will fight,
Follow me cloſe, Ile bring you too’t: Adieu.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Pleaſe you retyre to your Chamber?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Lead me:
He goes forth gallantly: That he and Cæſar might
Determine this great Warre in ſingle fight;
Then Anthony; but now. Well on.

scene.stagedir: Trumpets ſound. Enter Anthony, and Eros.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: The Gods make this a happy day to Anthony.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Would thou, & thoſe thy ſcars had once preuaild
To make me fight at Land.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Had’ſt thou done ſo,
The Kings that haue reuolted, and the Soldier
That has this morning left thee, would haue ſtill
Followed thy heeles.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Whoſe gone this morning?

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Who? one euer neere thee, call for Enobarbus,
He ſhall not heare thee, or from Cæſars Campe,
Say I am none of thine.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: What ſayeſt thou?

speech.speaker: Sold.
speech.line: Sir he is with Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Sir, his Cheſts and Treaſure he has not with him.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Is he gone?

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: Moſt certaine.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Go Eros, ſend his Treaſure after, do it,
Detaine no iot I charge thee: write to him,
(I will ſubſcribe) gentle adieu’s, and greetings;
Say, that I wiſh he neuer finde more cauſe
To change a Maſter. Oh my Fortunes haue
Corrupted honeſt men. Diſpatch Enobarbus. Exit

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter Agrippa, Cæſar, with Enobarbus, and Dollabella.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Go forth Agrippa, and begin the fight:
Our will is Anthony be tooke aliue:
Make it ſo knowne.

speech.speaker: Agrip.
speech.line: Cæſar, I ſhall.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: The time of vniuerſall peace is neere:
Proue this a proſp’rous day, the three nook’d world
Shall beare the Oliue freely.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Anthony is come into the Field.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Go charge Agrippa,
Plant thoſe that haue reuolted in the Vant,
That Anthony may ſeeme to ſpend his Fury
Vpon himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Alexas did reuolt, and went to Iewry on
Affaires of Anthony, there did diſſwade
Great Herod to incline himſelfe to Cæſar,
And leaue his Maſter Anthony. For this paines,
Cæſar hath hang’d him: Camindius and the reſt
That fell away, haue entertainment, but
No honourable truſt: I haue done ill,
Of which I do accuſe my ſelfe ſo ſorely,
That I will ioy no more.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: Enobarbus, Anthony
Hath after thee ſent all thy Treaſure, with
His Bounty ouer-plus. The Meſſenger
Came on my guard, and at thy Tent is now
Vnloading of his Mules.

speech.speaker: Eno.
speech.line: I giue it you.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: Mocke not Enobarbus,
I tell you true: Beſt you ſaf’t the bringer
Out of the hoaſt, I muſt attend mine Office,
Or would haue done’t my ſelfe. Your Emperor
Continues ſtill a Ioue. Exit

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: I am alone the Villaine of the earth,
And feele I am ſo moſt. Oh Anthony,
Thou Mine of Bounty, how would’ſt thou haue payed
My better ſeruice, when my turpitude
Thou doſt ſo Crowne with Gold. This blowes my hart,
If ſwift thought breake it not: a ſwifter meane
Shall out-strike thought, but thought will doo’t. I feele
I fight againſt thee: No I will go ſeeke
Some Ditch, wherein to dye: the foul’ſt beſt fits
My latter part of life. Exit.

scene.stagedir: Alarum, Drummes and Trumpets. Enter Agrippa.

speech.speaker: Agrip.
speech.line: Retire, we haue engag’d our ſelues too farre:
Cæſar himſelfe ha’s worke, and our oppreſſion
Exceeds what we expeƈted. Exit.

scene.stagedir: Alarums. Enter Anthony, and Scarrus wounded.

speech.speaker: Scar.
speech.line: O my braue Emperor, this is fought indeed,
Had we done ſo at firſt, we had drouen them home
With clowts about their heads.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Thou bleed’ſt apace.

speech.speaker: Scar.
speech.line: I had a wound heere that was like a T,
But now ’tis made an H.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: They do retyre.

speech.speaker: Scar.
speech.line: Wee’l beat ’em into Bench-holes, I haue yet
Roome for ſix ſcotches more.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: They are beaten Sir, and our aduantage ſerues
For a faire viƈtory.

speech.speaker: Scar.
speech.line: Let vs ſcore their backes,
And ſnatch ’em vp, as we take Hares behinde,
’Tis ſport to maul a Runner.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I will reward thee
Once for thy ſprightly comfort, and ten-fold
For thy good valour. Come thee on.

speech.speaker: Scar.
speech.line: Ile halt after.

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Enter Anthony againe in a March. Scarrus, with others.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: We haue beate him to his Campe: Runne one
Before, & let the Queen know of our gueſts: to morrow
Before the Sun ſhall ſee’s, wee’l ſpill the blood
That ha’s to day eſcap’d. I thanke you all,
For doughty handed are you, and haue fought
Not as you ſeru’d the Cauſe, but as’t had beene
Each mans like mine: you haue ſhewne all Heƈtors.
Enter the Citty, clip your Wiues, your Friends,
Tell them your feats, whil’ſt they with ioyfull teares
Waſh the congealement from your wounds, and kiſſe
The Honour’d-gaſhes whole.
Giue me thy hand,
To this great Faiery, Ile commend thy aƈts,
Make her thankes bleſſe thee. Oh thou day o’th’world,
Chaine mine arm’d necke, leape thou, Attyre and all
Through proofe of Harneſſe to my heart, and there
Ride on the pants triumphing.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Lord of Lords.
Oh infinite Vertue, comm’ſt thou ſmiling from
The worlds great ſnare vncaught.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Mine Nightingale,
We haue beate them to their Beds.
What Gyrle, though gray
Do ſomthing mingle with our yonger brown, yet ha we
A Braine that nouriſhes our Nerues, and can
Get gole for gole of youth. Behold this man,
Commend vnto his Lippes thy fauouring hand,
Kiſſe it my Warriour: He hath fought to day,
As if a God in hate of Mankinde, had
Deſtroyed in ſuch a ſhape.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Ile giue thee Friend
An Armour all of Gold: it was a Kings.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: He has deſeru’d it, were it Carbunkled
Like holy Phœbus Carre. Giue me thy hand,
Through Alexandria make a iolly March,
Beare our hackt Targets, like the men that owe them.
Had our great Pallace the capacity
To Campe this hoaſt, we all would ſup together,
And drinke Carowſes to the next dayes Fate
Which promiſes Royall perill, Trumpetters
With brazen dinne blaſt you the Citties eare,
Make mingle with our ratling Tabourines,
That heauen and earth may ſtrike their ſounds together,
Applauding our approach.

scene.stagedir: Enter a Centerie, and his Company, Enobarbus followes.

speech.speaker: Cent.
speech.line: If we be not releeu’d within this houre,
We muſt returne to’th’Court of Guard: the night
Is ſhiny, and they ſay, we ſhall embattaile
By’th’ſecond houre i’th’Morne.

speech.speaker: 1. Watch.
speech.line: This laſt day was a ſhrew’d one too’s.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Oh beare me witneſſe night.
What man is this?
Stand cloſe, and liſt him.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Be witneſſe to me (O thou bleſſed Moone)
When men reuolted ſhall vpon Record
Beare hatefull memory: poore Enobarbus did
Before thy face repent.

speech.speaker: Cent.
speech.line: Enobarbus?
Peace: Hearke further.

speech.speaker: Enob.
speech.line: Oh Soueraigne Miſtris of true Melancholly,
The poyſonous dampe of night diſpunge vpon me,
That Life, a very Rebell to my will,
May hang no longer on me. Throw my heart
Againſt the flint and hardneſſe of my fault,
Which being dried with greefe, will breake to powder,
And finiſh all foule thoughts. Oh Anthony,
Nobler then my reuolt is Infamous,
Forgiue me in thine owne particular,
But let the world ranke me in Regiſter
A Maſter leauer, and a fugitiue:
Oh Anthony! Oh Anthony!
Let’s ſpeake to him.

speech.speaker: Cent.
speech.line: Let’s heare him, for the things he ſpeakes
May concerne Cæſar.
Let’s do ſo; but he ſleepes.

speech.speaker: Cent.
speech.line: Swoonds rather, for ſo bad a Prayer as his
Was neuer yet for ſleepe.
Go we to him.
Awake ſir, awake, ſpeake to vs.
Heare you ſir?

speech.speaker: Cent.
speech.line: The hand of death hath raught him.
Hearke the Drummes demurely wake the ſleepers:
Let vs beare him to’th’Court of Guard: he is of note:
Our houre is fully out.
Come on then, he may recouer yet.

scene.stagedir: Enter Anthony and Scarrus, with their Army.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Their preparation is to day by Sea,
We pleaſe them not by Land.

speech.speaker: Scar.
speech.line: For both, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I would they’ld fight i’th’Fire, or i’th’Ayre,
Wee’ld fight there too. But this it is, our Foote
Vpon the hilles adioyning to the Citty
Shall ſtay with vs. Order for Sea is giuen,
They haue put forth the Hauen:
Where their appointment we may beſt diſcouer,
And looke on their endeuour.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: But being charg’d, we will be ſtill by Land,
Which as I tak’t we ſhall, for his beſt force
Is forth to Man his Gallies. To the Vales,
And hold our beſt aduantage.

scene.stagedir: Alarum afarre off, as at a Sea-fight. Enter Anthony, and Scarrus.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Yet they are not ioyn’d:
Where yon’d Pine does ſtand, I ſhall diſcouer all.
Ile bring thee word ſtraight, how ’tis like to go.

speech.speaker: Scar.
speech.line: Swallowes haue built
In Cleopatra’s Sailes their neſts. The Auguries
Say, they know not, they cannot tell, looke grimly,
And dare not ſpeake their knowledge. Anthony,
Is valiant, and deieƈted, and by ſtarts
His fretted Fortunes giue him hope and feare
Of what he has, and has not.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: All is loſt:
This fowle Egyptian hath betrayed me:
My Fleete hath yeelded to the Foe, and yonder
They caſt their Caps vp, and Carowſe together
Like Friends long loſt. Triple-turn’d Whore, ’tis thou
Haſt ſold me to this Nouice, and my heart
Makes onely Warres on thee. Bid them all flye:
For when I am reueng’d vpon my Charme,
I haue done all. Bid them all flye, be gone.
Oh Sunne, thy vpriſe ſhall I ſee no more,
Fortune, and Anthony part heere, euen heere
Do we ſhake hands? All come to this? The hearts
That pannelled me at heeles, to whom I gaue
Their wiſhes, do diſ-Candie, melt their ſweets
On bloſſoming Cæſar: And this Pine is barkt,
That ouer-top’d them all. Betray’d I am.
Oh this falſe Soule of Egypt! this graue Charme,
Whoſe eye beck’d forth my Wars, & cal’d them home:
Whoſe Boſome was my Crownet, my chiefe end,
Like a right Gypſie, hath at faſt and looſe
Beguil’d me, to the very heart of loſſe.
What Eros, Eros?
Ah, thou Spell! Auaunt.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Why is my Lord enrag’d againſt his Loue?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Vaniſh, or I ſhall giue thee thy deſeruing,
And blemiſh Cæſars Triumph. Let him take thee,
And hoiſt thee vp to the ſhouting Plebeians,
Follow his Chariot, like the greateſt ſpot
Of all thy Sex. Moſt Monſter-like be ſhewne
For poor’ſt Diminitiues, for Dolts, and let
Patient Oƈtauia, plough thy viſage vp
With her prepared nailes.
’Tis well th’art gone,
If it be well to liue. But better ’twere
Thou fell’ſt into my furie, for one death
Might haue preuented many. Eros, hoa!
The ſhirt of Neſſus is vpon me, teach me
Alcides, thou mine Anceſtor, thy rage.
Let me lodge Licas on the hornes o’th’Moone,
And with thoſe hands that graſpt the heauieſt Club,
Subdue my worthieſt ſelfe: The Witch ſhall die,
To the young Roman Boy ſhe hath ſold me, and I fall
Vnder this plot: She dyes for’t. Eros hoa?

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Helpe me my women: Oh hee’s more mad
Then Telamon for his Shield, the Boare of Theſſaly
Was neuer ſo imboſt.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: To’th’Monument, there locke your ſelfe,
And ſend him word you are dead:
The Soule and Body riue not more in parting,
Then greatneſſe going off.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: To’th’Monument:
Mardian, go tell him I haue ſlaine my ſelfe:
Say, that the laſt I ſpoke was Anthony,
And word it (prythee) pitteouſly. Hence Mardian,
And bring me how he takes my death to’th’Monument.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Eros, thou yet behold’ſt me?

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: I Noble Lord.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Sometime we ſee a clowd that’s Dragoniſh,
A vapour ſometime, like a Beare, or Lyon,
A toward Cittadell, a pendant Rocke,
A forked Mountaine, or blew Promontorie
With Trees vpon’t, that nodde vnto the world,
And mocke our eyes with Ayre.
Thou haſt ſeene theſe Signes,
They are blacke Veſpers Pageants.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: I my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: That which is now a Horſe, euen with a thoght
the Racke diſlimes, and makes it indiſtinƈt
As water is in water.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: It does my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: My good Knaue Eros, now thy Captaine is
Euen ſuch a body: Heere I am Anthony,
Yet cannot hold this viſible ſhape (my Knaue)
I made theſe warres for Egypt, and the Queene,
Whoſe heart I thought I had, for ſhe had mine:
Which whil’ſt it was mine, had annext vntoo’t
A Million moe, (now loſt:) ſhee Eros has
Packt Cards with Cæſars, and falſe plaid my Glory
Vnto an Enemies triumph.
Nay, weepe not gentle Eros, there is left vs
Our ſelues to end our ſelues.
Oh thy vilde Lady, ſhe has rob’d me of my Sword.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No Anthony,
My Miſtris lou’d thee, and her Fortunes mingled
With thine intirely.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Hence ſawcy Eunuch peace, ſhe hath betraid me,
And ſhall dye the death.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Death of one perſon, can be paide but once,
And that ſhe ha’s diſcharg’d. What thou would’ſt do
Is done vnto thy hand: the laſt ſhe ſpake
Was Anthony, moſt Noble Anthony.
Then in the midd’ſt a tearing grone did breake
The name of Anthony: it was diuided
Betweene her heart, and lips: ſhe tendred life
Thy name ſo buried in her.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Dead then?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Dead.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Vnarme Eros, the long dayes taske is done,
And we muſt ſleepe: That thou depart’ſt hence ſafe
Does pay thy labour richly: Go. exit Mardian.
Off, plucke off,
The ſeuen-fold ſhield of Aiax cannot keepe
The battery from my heart. Oh cleaue my ſides.
Heart, once be ſtronger then thy Continent,
Cracke thy fraile Caſe. Apace Eros, apace;
No more a Soldier: bruiſed peeces go,
You haue bin Nobly borne. From me awhile.
I will o’re-take thee Cleopatra, and
Weepe for my pardon. So it muſt be, for now
All length is Torture: ſince the Torch is out,
Lye downe and ſtray no farther. Now all labour
Marres what it does: yea, very force entangles
It ſelfe with ſtrength: Seale then and all is done.
Eros? I come my Queene. Eros? Stay for me,
Where Soules do couch on Flowers, wee’l hand in hand,
And with our ſprightly Port make the Ghoſtes gaze:
Dido, and her Æneas ſhall want Troopes,
And all the haunt be ours. Come Eros, Eros.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: What would my Lord?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Since Cleopatra dyed,
I haue liu’d in ſuch diſhonour, that the Gods
Deteſt my baſeneſſe. I, that with my Sword,
Quarter’d the World, and o’re greene Neptunes backe
With Ships, made Cities; condemne my ſelfe, to lacke
The Courage of a Woman, leſſe Noble minde
Then ſhe which by her death, our Cæſar telles
I am Conqueror of my ſelfe. Thou art ſworne Eros,
That when the exigent ſhould come, which now
Is come indeed: When I ſhould ſee behinde me
Th’ineuitable proſecution of diſgrace and horror,
That on my command, thou then would’ſt kill me.
Doo’t, the time is come: Thou ſtrik’ſt not me,
’Tis Cæſar thou defeat’ſt. Put colour in thy Cheeke.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: The Gods with-hold me,
Shall I do that which all the Parthian Darts,
(Though Enemy) loſt ayme, and could not.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Eros,
Would’ſt thou be window’d in great Rome, and ſee
Thy Maſter thus with pleacht Armes, bending downe
His corrigible necke, his face ſubdu’de
To penetratiue ſhame; whil’ſt the wheel’d ſeate
Of Fortunate Cæſar drawne before him, branded
His Baſeneſſe that enſued.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: I would not ſee’t.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Come then: for with a wound I muſt be cur’d.
Draw that thy honeſt Sword, which thou haſt worne
Moſt vſefull for thy Country.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Oh ſir, pardon me.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: When I did make thee free, ſwor’ſt ӳ not then
To do this when I bad thee? Do it at once,
Or thy precedent Seruices are all
But accidents vnpurpos’d. Draw, and come.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Turne from me then that Noble countenance,
Wherein the worſhip of the whole world lyes.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Loe thee.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: My ſword is drawne.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Then let it do at once
The thing why thou haſt drawne it.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: My deere Maſter,
My Captaine, and my Emperor. Let me ſay
Before I ſtrike this bloody ſtroke, Farwell.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: ’Tis ſaid man, and farewell.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Farewell great Chiefe. Shall I ſtrike now?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Now Eros.

speech.speaker: Eros.
speech.line: Why there then:
Thus I do eſcape the ſorrow of Anthonies death.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Thrice-Nobler then my ſelfe,
Thou teacheſt me: Oh valiant Eros, what
I ſhould, and thou could’ſt not, my Queene and Eros
Haue by their braue inſtruƈtion got vpon me
A Nobleneſſe in Record. But I will bee
A Bride-groome in my death, and run intoo’t
As to a Louers bed. Come then, and Eros,
Thy Maſter dies thy Scholler; to do thus
I learnt of thee. How, not dead? Not dead?
The Guard, how? Oh diſpatch me.

speech.speaker: 1. Guard.
speech.line: What’s the noiſe?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I haue done my worke ill Friends:
Oh make an end of what I haue begun.
The Starre is falne.
And time is at his Period.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Alas, and woe.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Let him that loues me, ſtrike me dead.
Not I.
Nor I.
Nor any one.

speech.speaker: Decretus.
speech.line: Thy death and fortunes bid thy folowers fly
This ſword but ſhewne to Cæſar with this tydings,
Shall enter me with him.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Where’s Anthony?

speech.speaker: Decre.
speech.line: There Diomed there.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Liues he: wilt thou not anſwer man?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Art thou there Diomed?
Draw thy ſword, and giue mee,
Suffiſing ſtrokes for death.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Moſt abſolute Lord:
My Miſtris Cleopatra ſent me to thee.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: When did ſhee ſend thee?

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Now my Lord.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Where is ſhe?

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Lockt in her Monument: ſhe had a Propheſying feare
Of what hath come to paſſe: for when ſhe ſaw
(Which neuer ſhall be found) you did ſuſpeƈt
She had diſpos’d with Cæſar, and that your rage
Would not be purg’d, ſhe ſent you word ſhe was dead:
But fearing ſince how it might worke, hath ſent
Me to proclaime the truth, and I am come
I dread, too late.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Too late good Diomed: call my Guard I prythee.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: What hoa: the Emperors Guard,
The Guard, what hoa? Come, your Lord calles.

scene.stagedir: Enter 4. or 5. of the Guard of Anthony.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Beare me good Friends where Cleopatra bides,
’Tis the laſt ſeruice that I ſhall command you.
Woe, woe are we ſir, you may not liue to weare
All your true Followers out.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Moſt heauy day.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Nay good my Fellowes, do not pleaſe ſharp fate
To grace it with your ſorrowes. Bid that welcome
Which comes to puniſh vs, and we puniſh it
Seeming to beare it lightly. Take me vp,
I haue led you oft, carry me now good Friends,
And haue my thankes for all.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cleopatra, and her Maides aloft, with Charmian & Iras.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Oh Charmian, I will neuer go from hence.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Be comforted deere Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: No, I will not:
All ſtrange and terrible euents are welcome,
But comforts we dispiſe; our ſize of ſorrow
Proportion’d to our cauſe, muſt be as great
As that which makes it.
How now? is he dead?

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: His death’s vpon him, but not dead.
Looke out o’th other ſide your Monument,
His Guard haue brought him thither.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Oh Sunne,
Burne the great Sphere thou mou’ſt in, darkling ſtand
The varrying ſhore o’th’world. O Antony, Antony, Antony
Helpe Charmian, helpe Iras helpe: helpe Friends
Below, let’s draw him hither.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Peace,
Not Cæſars Valour hath o’rethrowne Anthony,
But Anthonie’s hath Triumpht on it ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: So it ſhould be,
That none but Anthony ſhould conquer Anthony,
But woe ’tis ſo.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I am dying Egypt, dying; onely
I heere importune death a-while, vntill
Of many thouſand kiſſes, the poore laſt
I lay vpon thy lippes.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I dare not Deere,
Deere my Lord pardon: I dare not,
Leaſt I be taken: nor th’Imperious ſhew
Of the full-Fortun’d Cæſar, euer ſhall
Be brooch’d with me, if Knife, Drugges, Serpents haue
Edge, ſting, or operation. I am ſafe:
Your Wife Oƈtauia, with her modeſt eyes,
And ſtill Concluſion, ſhall acquire no Honour
Demuring vpon me: but come, come Anthony,
Helpe me my women, we muſt draw thee vp:
Aſſiſt good Friends.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Oh quicke, or I am gone.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Heere’s ſport indeede:
How heauy weighes my Lord?
Our ſtrength is all gone into heauineſſe,
That makes the waight. Had I great Iuno’s power,
The ſtrong wing’d Mercury ſhould fetch thee vp,
And ſet thee by Ioues ſide. Yet come a little,
Wiſhers were euer Fooles. Oh come, come, come,

line.stagedir: They heaue Anthony aloft to Cleopatra.

speech.line: And welcome, welcome. Dye when thou haſt liu’d,
Quicken with kiſſing: had my lippes that power,
Thus would I weare them out.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: A heauy ſight.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I am dying Egypt, dying.
Giue me ſome Wine, and let me ſpeake a little.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: No, let me ſpeake, and let me rayle ſo hye,
That the falſe Huſwife Fortune, breake her Wheele,
Prouok’d by my offence.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: One word (ſweet Queene)
Of Cæſar ſeeke your Honour, with your ſafety. Oh.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: They do not go together.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Gentle heare me,
None about Cæſar truſt, but Proculeius.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: My Reſolution, and my hands, Ile truſt,
None about Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: The miſerable change now at my end,
Lament nor ſorrow at: but pleaſe your thoughts
In feeding them with thoſe my former Fortunes
Wherein I liued. The greateſt Prince o’th’world,
The Nobleſt: and do now not baſely dye,
Not Cowardly put off my Helmet to
My Countreyman. A Roman, by a Roman
Valiantly vanquiſh’d. Now my Spirit is going,
I can no more.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Nobleſt of men, woo’t dye?
Haſt thou no care of me, ſhall I abide
In this dull world, which in thy abſence is
No better then a Stye? Oh ſee my women:
The Crowne o’th’earth doth melt. My Lord?
Oh wither’d is the Garland of the Warre,
The Souldiers pole is falne: young Boyes and Gyrles
Are leuell now with men: The oddes is gone,
And there is nothing left remarkeable
Beneath the viſiting Moone.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Oh quietneſſe, Lady.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: She’s dead too, our Soueraigne.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Lady.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: Madam.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Oh Madam, Madam, Madam.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: Royall Egypt: Empreſſe.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Peace, peace, Iras.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: No more but in a Woman, and commanded
By ſuch poore paſſion, as the Maid that Milkes,
And doe’s the meaneſt chares. It were for me,
To throw my Scepter at the iniurious Gods,
To tell them that this World did equall theyrs,
Till they had ſtolne our Iewell. All’s but naught:
Patience is ſottiſh, and impatience does
Become a Dogge that’s mad: Then is it ſinne,
To ruſh into the ſecret houſe of death,
Ere death dare come to vs. How do you Women?
What, what good cheere? Why how now Charmian?
My Noble Gyrles? Ah Women, women! Looke
Our Lampe is ſpent, it’s out. Good ſirs, take heart,
Wee’l bury him: And then, what’s braue, what’s Noble,
Let’s doo’t after the high Roman faſhion,
And make death proud to take vs. Come, away,
This caſe of that huge Spirit now is cold.
Ah Women, Women! Come, we haue no Friend
But Reſolution, and the breefeſt end.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cæſar, Agrippa, Dollabella, Menas, with his Counſell of Warre.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Go to him Dollabella, bid him yeeld,
Being ſo fruſtrate, tell him,
He mockes the pawſes that he makes.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Cæſar, I ſhall.

scene.stagedir: Enter Decretas with the ſword of Anthony.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Wherefore is that? And what art thou that dar’ſt
Appeare thus to vs?

speech.speaker: Dec.
speech.line: I am call’d Decretas,
Marke Anthony I ſeru’d, who beſt was worthie
Beſt to be ſeru’d: whil’ſt he ſtood vp, and ſpoke
He was my Maſter, and I wore my life
To ſpend vpon his haters. If thou pleaſe
To take me to thee, as I was to him,
Ile be to Cæſar: if ӳ pleaſeſt not, I yeild thee vp my life.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: What is’t thou ſay’ſt?

speech.speaker: Dec.
speech.line: I ſay (Oh Cæſar) Anthony is dead.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: The breaking of ſo great a thing, ſhould make
A greater cracke. The round World
Should haue ſhooke Lyons into ciuill ſtreets,
And Cittizens to their dennes. The death of Anthony
Is not a ſingle doome, in the name lay
A moity of the world.

speech.speaker: Dec.
speech.line: He is dead Cæſar,
Not by a publike miniſter of Iuſtice,
Nor by a hyred Knife, but that ſelfe-hand
Which writ his Honor in the Aƈts it did,
Hath with the Courage which the heart did lend it,
Splitted the heart. This is his Sword,
I robb’d his wound of it: behold it ſtain’d
With his moſt Noble blood.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Looke you ſad Friends,
The Gods rebuke me, but it is Tydings
To waſh the eyes of Kings.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: And ſtrange it is,
That Nature muſt compell vs to lament
Our moſt perſiſted deeds.

speech.speaker: Mec.
speech.line: His taints and Honours, wag’d equal with him.

speech.speaker: Dola.
speech.line: A Rarer ſpirit neuer
Did ſteere humanity: but you Gods will giue vs
Some faults to make vs men. Cæſar is touch’d.

speech.speaker: Mec.
speech.line: When ſuch a ſpacious Mirror’s ſet before him,
He needes muſt ſee him ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Oh Anthony,
I haue followed thee to this, but we do launch
Diſeaſes in our Bodies. I muſt perforce
Haue ſhewne to thee ſuch a declining day,
Or looke on thine: we could not ſtall together,
In the whole world. But yet let me lament
With teares as Soueraigne as the blood of hearts,
That thou my Brother, my Competitor,
In top of all deſigne; my Mate in Empire,
Friend and Companion in the front of Warre,
The Arme of mine owne Body, and the Heart
Where mine his thoughts did kindle; that our Starres
Vnreconciliable, ſhould diuide our equalneſſe to this.
Heare me good Friends,
But I will tell you at ſome meeter Seaſon,
The buſineſſe of this man lookes out of him,
Wee’l heare him what he ſayes.
Whence are you?

speech.speaker: Ægyp.
speech.line: A poore Egyptian yet, the Queen my miſtris
Confin’d in all, ſhe has her Monument
Of thy intents, deſires, inſtruƈtion,
That ſhe preparedly may frame her ſelfe
To’th’way ſhee’s forc’d too.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Bid her haue good heart,
She ſoone ſhall know of vs, by ſome of ours,
How honourable, and how kindely Wee
Determine for her. For Cæſar cannot leaue to be vngentle

speech.speaker: Ægypt.
speech.line: So the Gods preſerue thee.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Come hither Proculeius. Go and ſay
We purpoſe her no ſhame: giue her what comforts
The quality of her paſſion ſhall require;
Leaſt in her greatneſſe, by ſome mortall ſtroke
She do defeate vs. For her life in Rome,
Would be eternall in our Triumph: Go,
And with your ſpeedieſt bring vs what ſhe ſayes,
And how you finde of her.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Cæſar I ſhall. Exit Proculeius.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Gallus, go you along: where’s Dolabella, to ſe-
cond Proculeius?

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Dolabella.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Let him alone: for I remember now
How hee’s imployd: he ſhall in time be ready.
Go with me to my Tent, where you ſhall ſee
How hardly I was drawne into this Warre,
How calme and gentle I proceeded ſtill
In all my Writings. Go with me, and ſee
What I can ſhew in this.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Mardian.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: My deſolation does begin to make
A better life: Tis paltry to be Cæſar:
Not being Fortune, hee’s but Fortunes knaue,
A miniſter of her will: and it is great
To do that thing that ends all other deeds,
Which ſhackles accedents, and bolts vp change;
Which ſleepes, and neuer pallates more the dung,
The beggers Nurſe, and Cæſars.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Cæſar ſends greeting to the Queene of Egypt,
And bids thee ſtudy on what faire demands
Thou mean’ſt to haue him grant thee.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: What’s thy name?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: My name is Proculeius.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Did tell me of you, bad me truſt you, but
I do not greatly care to be deceiu’d
That haue no vſe for truſting. If your Maſter
Would haue a Queene his begger, you muſt tell him,
That Maieſty to keepe decorum, muſt
No leſſe begge then a Kingdome: If he pleaſe
To giue me conquer’d Egypt for my Sonne,
He giues me ſo much of mine owne, as I
Will kneele to him with thankes.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Be of good cheere:
Y’are falne into a Princely hand, feare nothing,
Make your full reference freely to my Lord,
Who is ſo full of Grace, that it flowes ouer
On all that neede. Let me report to him
Your ſweet dependancie, and you ſhall finde
A Conqueror that will pray in ayde for kindneſſe,
Where he for grace is kneel’d too.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Pray you tell him,
I am his Fortunes Vaſſall, and I ſend him
The Greatneſſe he has got. I hourely learne
A Doƈtrine of Obedience, and would gladly
Looke him i’th’Face.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: This Ile report (deere Lady)
Haue comfort, for I know your plight is pittied
Of him that caus’d it.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: You ſee how eaſily ſhe may be ſurpriz’d:
Guard her till Cæſar come.

speech.speaker: Iras.
speech.line: Royall Queene.

speech.speaker: Char.
speech.line: Oh Cleopatra, thou art taken Queene.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Quicke, quicke, good hands.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Hold worthy Lady, hold:
Doe not your ſelfe ſuch wrong, who are in this
Releeu’d, but not betraid.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: What of death too that rids our dogs of languiſh

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Cleopatra, do not abuſe my Maſters bounty, by
Th’vndoing of your ſelfe: Let the World ſee
His Nobleneſſe well aƈted, which your death
Will neuer let come forth.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Where art thou Death?
Come hither come; Come, come, and take a Queene
Worth many Babes and Beggers.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Oh temperance Lady.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Sir, I will eate no meate, Ile not drinke ſir,
If idle talke will once be neceſſary
Ile not ſleepe neither. This mortall houſe Ile ruine,
Do Cæſar what he can. Know ſir, that I
Will not waite pinnion’d at your Maſters Court,
Nor once be chaſtic’d with the ſober eye
Of dull Oƈtauia. Shall they hoyſt me vp,
And ſhew me to the ſhowting Varlotarie
Of cenſuring Rome? Rather a ditch in Egypt.
Be gentle graue vnto me, rather on Nylus mudde
Lay me ſtarke-nak’d, and let the water-Flies
Blow me into abhorring; rather make
My Countries high pyramides my Gibbet,
And hang me vp in Chaines.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: You do extend
Theſe thoughts of horror further then you ſhall
Finde cauſe in Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Proculeius,
What thou haſt done, thy Maſter Cæſar knowes,
And he hath ſent for thee: for the Queene,
Ile take her to my Guard.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: So Dolabella,
It ſhall content me beſt: Be gentle to her,
To Cæſar I will ſpeake, what you ſhall pleaſe,
If you’l imploy me to him.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Say, I would dye.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Moſt Noble Empreſſe, you haue heard of me.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I cannot tell.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Aſſuredly you know me.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: No matter ſir, what I haue heard or knowne:
You laugh when Boyes or Women tell their Dreames,
Is’t not your tricke?

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I vnderſtand not, Madam.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I dreampt there was an Emperor Anthony.
Oh ſuch another ſleepe, that I might ſee
But ſuch another man.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: If it might pleaſe ye.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: His face was as the Heau’ns, and therein ſtucke
A Sunne and Moone, which kept their courſe, & lighted
The little o’th’earth.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Moſt Soueraigne Creature.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: His legges beſtrid the Ocean, his rear’d arme
Creſted the world: His voyce was propertied
As all the tuned Spheres, and that to Friends:
But when he meant to quaile, and ſhake the Orbe,
He was as ratling Thunder. For his Bounty,
There was no winter in’t. An Anthony it was,
That grew the more by reaping: His delights
Were Dolphin-like, they ſhew’d his backe aboue
The Element they liu’d in: In his Liuery
Walk’d Crownes and Crownets: Realms & Iſlands were
As plates dropt from his pocket.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Cleopatra.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Thinke you there was, or might be ſuch a man
As this I dreampt of?

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Gentle Madam, no.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: You Lye vp to the hearing of the Gods:
But if there be, not euer were one ſuch
It’s paſt the ſize of dreaming: Nature wants ſtuffe
To vie ſtrange formes with fancie, yet t’imagine
An Anthony were Natures peece, ’gainſt Fancie,
Condemning ſhadowes quite.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Heare me, good Madam:
Your loſſe is as your ſelfe, great; and you beare it
As anſwering to the waight, would I might neuer
Ore-take purſu’de ſucceſſe: But I do feele
By the rebound of yours, a greefe that ſuites
My very heart at roote.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: I thanke you ſir:
Know you what Cæſar meanes to do with me?

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I am loath to tell you what, I would you knew.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Nay pray you ſir.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Though he be Honourable.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Hee’l leade me then in Triumph.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Madam he will, I know’t.

scene.stagedir: Enter Proculeius, Cæſar, Gallus, Mecenas, and others of his Traine.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Make way there Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Cæſ.
speech.line: Which is the Queene of Egypt.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: It is the Emperor Madam.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Ariſe, you ſhall not kneele:
I pray you riſe, riſe Egypt.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Sir, the Gods will haue it thus,
My Maſter and my Lord I muſt obey,

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Take to you no hard thoughts,
The Record of what iniuries you did vs,
Though written in our fleſh, we ſhall remember
As things but done by chance.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Sole Sir o’th’World,
I cannot proieƈt mine owne cauſe ſo well
To make it cleare, but do confeſſe I haue
Bene laden with like frailties, which before
Haue often ſham’d our Sex.

speech.speaker: Cæſar.
speech.line: Cleopatra know,
We will extenuate rather then inforce:
If you apply your ſelfe to our intents,
Which towards you are moſt gentle, you ſhall finde
A benefit in this change: but if you ſeeke
To lay on me a Cruelty, by taking
Anthonies courſe, you ſhall bereaue your ſelfe
Of my good purpoſes, and put your children
To that deſtruƈtion which Ile guard them from,
If thereon you relye. Ile take my leaue.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
